33026613.subject: [Bacch-talk]  Harvard-Radcliffe Orchestra and the Harvard Choruses Present: Verdi's Requiem
33026613.text:
HARVARD-RADCLIFFE ORCHESTRA AND
THE HARVARD CHORUSES PRESENT...

*VERDI'S REQUIEM* IN CONJUNCTION WITH FEATURED SOLOISTS

Join the Harvard-Radcliffe Orchestra and the Harvard Choruses (Harvard Glee
Club, Radcliffe Choral Society, Harvard-Radcliffe Collegium Musicum) for a
monumental performance of Verdi’s Requiem on Sunday, April 30th at 3 PM in
Sanders Theater! Under the baton of HRO Music Director Federico Cortese,
250 Harvard students will perform alongside world-renowned soloists Raquel
Gonzalez (Soprano), Renee Tatum (Mezzo-Soprano), Cooper Nolan (Tenor), and
Weston Hurt (Bass). We’re so excited to welcome you to Sanders Theatre!

Tickets are $10 for Harvard Students with HUID and $30 for General
Admission. You can buy them at the Box Office or from any HRO or Harvard
Choruses member. VIP Preferred Seating ($50) in Center Mezzanine and Center
Balcony is also available from manager@harvardgleeclub.org.

For any questions, please contact hro@hrorchestra.org or
manager@harvardgleeclub.org. We hope to see you there!
Sunday,
April 2023
303:00 p.m.
Get tickets today —
seats are selling out fast!

<https://notifications.google.com/g/p/ACUgQrH3xqsjYzi8dmsZRgM48ndHmhqMhvRvNV6fri_e4FboAKElQFFhv3-IFvq-8I2b9UwkojsyeqVNldGATggT2Typ5kjnu4MLLPWDq1Xp0bz8vFBEcMKto5Oo-TlcDD0f8pGFadqg8KY6-GjXMGLY0OkQ8A-T9u27WzWWS14wHyMCilLGcFgkoR_VEu3TdYR8sFmrvux4wNdDnET2EmeJPhh4a3m7JEs7EH1RfXghsactvI0Qhw0ar1G9if_bpb8g-YB5RMqBAlkfa1XrlVHAttFe9ux862gnzYs4wNEthoxkm8h6u4KRNYqn7mgvkQLwcb29rG5SbcZWwvc8DgRq8VyeUzuzZ2N8UiUHy5xoUxk2jZbIEYK0IhkphVGWGLc>

Hi Andy,

Google I/O is just around the corner and we thought you’d be interested in two Google Maps Platform technical sessions where you will learn about new capabilities to create next-gen immersive maps and to use data-driven styling and advanced markers to provide richer user experiences. Register for this live streaming event and join developers from around the world for networking, meetups, collaboration, and more.

Tech Sessions:

Create immersive map experiences with new capabilities <https://notifications.google.com/g/p/ACUgQrG0BlhKUgiMIt-IS9zowxF3oiFvTCSbRrTkB-tuOtTppHItr0QH2MuR-LtBRJ-H0Z3qncmkkM2XcQD-PjlpcLDjnt8Wj2hc9LIb8JUsvTQNteUcoHv0Fs3Gmo0GBRskgyRLp7BYU8pGk_zC_1CWdUAEulce_rOSe1tbA9ZB5uP3WuGg0b5pjRu28bDdvii7jDiBwqEGDPnKiz8o3ijPRTAz44refQqkyYdAqmnYWafBM_bO3_YGHHODZ-JRtsgLBs4SgJWqESmOtfHtWw_hog5Ar1zrhGwpangsgKtuY-NleFyMO_NuumYQk2zrZxgWi_ICr8FNEP3DOapF6EbQqbsN0VPD7P-rhdlQK8iz9AA59ANDSOqsrYNWftxqboTgNVuKGVB7O1Pxrz56tGiF2k6db0MusLXbWDEJSUgl6g9QY2gJmh6Y3YmQ1ze9QvL1XfvVAAhXeaeydcai5tG3sP7E4XJ-lxYFfh8Wtys4L4iyrtrA3mQM4X9-PQ>
Create immersive map visualization experiences directly in your web app with new capabilities in Google Maps Platform. Learn more about how to create customized map visualization experiences using these new capabilities in this technical session.

Use data-driven, advanced styling to build immersive map experiences <https://notifications.google.com/g/p/ACUgQrFrCaeig6cp4kGt2FAN_M89FLQbFrJPIeu0_lePvFFQcATzNqR-gwH2RJ6-B0pj-kMdIjreLrGKYNa-sOxfG9-SCWQac7JCxfPwyG_OC1mn5bSAXD_mV7ZoGlJkyFItVY1lJieHaK-0OyISmLQcTB5d_VSpn-Xwp8ARl7Y_o5Iit3Up6wO-DjRjCxIqpAdTjiV6ffVrwWY-GsKuR4GtWNuiZvT1fV-nYzROiaHeo2mVK8_ZWR2gDcNKz-IZrm4uvWXkRrGjXL7UIBCpwjT1RGE9d2wIR8J04xUhx7S1FpR2U81lRtrG26JbW47BVABn3PxGtFb2zEeRWD1HVn6uM5pwMslfgAzXoAAuaPShn0T045daN9QaLOoQJXyIHZ3eASktDD2dw1cs4CwbXx46B7IvUWVMA8Xe9AW-k7QuCyCF4l26zZJpOj-hZ0Ixd1W7lutHnKBnno8MZuWQ5fB_FiTBnlX_ZF_CEUVfNDhixdvvAL6bax-2aF_CEWPTX_8a6n3bBxR2P_0>
Build highly customized maps to provide a richer user experience and showcase your brand, with new Google Maps Platform capabilities. Use data-driven styling to display and style Google’s polygons for administrative boundaries with your business data, and learn about brand new styling capabilities. Utilize advanced markers to create customized, more performant markers to help differentiate your brand. Learn how to use these tools to easily create more engaging, custom map experiences.

Don’t miss out on these sessions and so much more!

Register now <https://notifications.google.com/g/p/ACUgQrEZlsjaC3RdkV-N9QOfwFQuP7ZaAU7frEN6uRL2hN005iZ9gpRyKDDNegw0dSSn5i3ktqI2CYU3wqDDwEFX-qYkKn1JbahW452TipHghf3UHExREQ96AY54t39ufluRxiOmXrS7rmsyrVuJxO4-1eqCHqyPPJMEWwVOhR1Zb_3Dp_SSDzsCv-mMTblOcZurjDgbKmvbgM9QQKOxAoIOY0HubqcDjd5SC0dabiJ-RiDVw5LIBupceVHgFgCr0UWniMZvE5EF51e6Ka4-_xD6jXjaHyqNuMByvx1fc_toDWAdn1mtAJSDFu4mUszNEPW3EVPWcqjH8zTynr_dvbiwI3thIrvKJlDgSwpCyE9k0BPrrwBE_L8p0PbsDlA4rOAYmJu0>

76042905.subject: 2023 Enrolled Student Survey
76042905.text:
Dear Harvard Student,

I ask you to take some time to take a survey about your academic, social, and extra-curricular experiences over this past year.   This is an opportunity for you to tell us about your experiences with your concentration, academic support services, social experiences and your wellbeing.  We take your feedback seriously.  Survey results, including your comments, will be shared anonymously and without attribution with members of our faculty and administration to help with decision-making.

To access the survey, click on the link below.  You will need to devote approximately 5-10 minutes to the survey.  Please take the survey early!  The link will be available through May 1st.

https://harvard.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_8GgXw9ALHQcEZ0i

If you encounter any problems accessing the survey, please contact the Institutional Research staff at hcir@fas.harvard.edu<mailto:hcir@fas.harvard.edu>.

Thank you for your care in answering the survey questions and best wishes for the rest of your spring semester.


Warmest regards,

Rakesh Khurana

Danoff Dean of Harvard College

101497457.subject: [HUES] HUES Board elections happening TOMORROW 1 P.M
101497457.text:
Hey engineers!

Candidacy statements for 2023-2024 HUES Board positions are attached below!

*The election will take place TOMORROW on Friday**, April 28th *from
12:00PM - 3:00PM EDT*, but will likely not take the entire allocated time.* We
will be meeting in *Sever Hall, room 102. * Everyone is invited to join us!
Please take part in choosing the individuals who will be representing our
engineers in this board next year.


Because the meeting is relatively long, voters can come and go, but *if
you're running for a position please try to stay the whole time. **If you
are running for a position, but are unable to attend
the election deliberations, please email mwieczorek@college.harvard.edu
<gracekim@college.harvard.edu>** as soon as possible.*


*Please email me (mwieczorek@college.harvard.edu
<gracekim@college.harvard.edu>) or Molly (mollybosworth@college.harvard.edu
<mollybosworth@college.harvard.edu>) with any questions!*

A reminder about voting/election procedures is below.

*Voting/Election:*


   - *The election is open to all members of the hues-open list who would
   like to come for deliberations and voting.*
   - Because the meeting is relatively long, voters can come and go, but *if
   you're running for a position please try to stay the whole time (please let
   us know if you can only stay part of the time.)*
   -  Please keep speeches to under 3 minutes.
   - You may not take part in the deliberations for any position you are
   running for; you will be in a different room while deliberations happen
   among voters.
   - For each position, the candidate with the most votes will be elected -
   for positions with 2 chairs, the candidates with the top 2 most votes will
   be elected.

Please let me or Molly <mollybosworth@college.harvard.edu> know if you have
any questions, and I hope to see lots of you tomorrow!
-- 
Maycee Wieczorek
Harvard College Class of 2024
S.B Candidate in Mechanical Engineering

--

To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to hues-open-list+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.
To view this discussion on the web visit https://groups.google.com/d/msgid/hues-open-list/CAGCz6%2B%3DXAew%2BJUt55ks%3DMKDBkabtTjTcm4on7RG2JhKr81wSOg%40mail.gmail.com.

120593539.text:

Continue reading the main story

Marquee Ad
[https://liveintent.newyorktimesinfo.com/imp?s=859181&li=NN&m=fa60ce664779ffc4229588105bf228e7&p=NN_20230430]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/5OpkDSAg8PWnW4QtkL9CHQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmMNWYP0SWaHR0cHM6Ly9saXZlaW50ZW50Lm5ld3lvcmt0aW1lc2luZm8uY29tL2NsaWNrP3M9ODU5MTgxJmxpPU5OJm09ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTcmcD1OTl8yMDIzMDQzMCZ0ZT0xJm5sPXRoZS1tb3JuaW5nJmVtYz1lZGl0X25uXzIwMjMwNDMwVwNueXRCCmQ_mFBOZO26y7VSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~

[https://static.nytimes.com/email-images/N-TheMorning%402x.png]

April 30, 2023

Madison Malone Kircher writes about internet culture for The Times, and she’s
the author of a new newsletter called It Happened Online. It will explain and
analyze the stories that have people talking. We’re turning over today’s edition
of The Morning to Madison so she can make sense of Twitter’s recent overhaul of
its blue check marks. — David Leonhardt



Author Headshot
[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2022/09/29/reader-center/author-madison-malone-kircher/author-madison-malone-kircher-blogSmallThumb.png]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/MeGAotuvpIbObjZ1r1PkpA~~/AAAAAQA~

By Madison Malone Kircher
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/MeGAotuvpIbObjZ1r1PkpA~~/AAAAAQA~]

Good morning. Now that anyone can be verified on Twitter, the accompanying blue
check means very little.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/30/fashion/30-THE-MORNING-NL-social/30-THE-MORNING-NL-social-jumbo.jpg]Gregory
Bull/Associated Press


SOCIAL STATUS

I got my verified Twitter check mark about eight years ago while working as a
cub reporter at a digital news outlet. I did nothing to earn it other than show
up to work one day and Oh, hey, would you look at that! I’m verified. Sweet!

(Technically, the check mark was white, surrounded by blue, but colloquially
they’ve become known as blue checks and I’m not about to squabble over semantics
now.)

It feels a little pathetic to reflect on how excited I was about getting a check
mark, but that was still the era when digital journalism was fighting to be
taken seriously. Getting that check, which denoted that Twitter had confirmed
the identity of the account’s owner and operator, gave me credibility.

Last week, after much throat clearing, Twitter started removing the check marks
from previously verified accounts whose users had declined to pay a fee — which
was most of them. Now, anyone can be “verified” on Twitter. It’ll cost you $8 a
month and comes with basically none of the usefulness that verification used to
offer because Twitter is no longer confirming that people are who they say they
are.

The change in verification is one of the most visible effects that Elon Musk has
had on Twitter since he bought it last year. Information on the platform, once
considered indispensable for following breaking news, has become increasingly
unreliable
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/Snu1C7deaUhTCrP1CsIlSQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmMNWYP0TmaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNi90ZWNobm9sb2d5L3R3aXR0ZXItdmVyaWZpY2F0aW9uLXByb2JsZW1zLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQzMCZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTQyNSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTc0MiZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD-YUE5k7brLtVIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~].
And for users who rely on Twitter to follow celebrities or other figures, the
verification change is part of a shift that will make many prominent users less
visible because they declined to pay to retain their check marks.

By the time Musk announced that all previously verified users would be losing
their status, a blue check was nothing to be proud of. Some users are now
calling it “the dreaded mark” or that “stinking badge,” my colleagues Callie
Holtermann and Lora Kelley reported last week
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/_Lz4-vjMUZPU3lYeQPEjrA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmMNWYP0TXaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNS9zdHlsZS90d2l0dGVyLWNoZWNrLW1hcmtzLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQzMCZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTQyNSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTc0MiZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD-YUE5k7brLtVIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~].

The icon makes its owner appear “desperate for validation,” according to the
rapper Doja Cat. Twitter also restored blue checks for popular users who didn’t
want them, including LeBron James, Bette Midler and Stephen King. The model and
internet personality Chrissy Teigen called her blue check a form of
“punishment.”

I would argue that the blue check was never as covetable as Musk thought it was.
(He has called it a “lords & peasants system.”) For me and many other
journalists, it was essentially just a tool to prove to sources I was who I said
I was. No different than a press badge or a business card.

Why should anyone care about the check mark changes, especially if their job
doesn’t involve sliding into DMs? Twitter’s check mark system wasn’t perfect,
but it did make it easier for users to figure out if tweets were coming from a
real person or organization, or from, say, an account pretending to be Eli Lilly
and promising free insulin for all. (This really happened
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/oVB1yxkZtTLRbJWgKUR9OA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmMNWYP0TjaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMi8xMS8xMS90ZWNobm9sb2d5L3R3aXR0ZXItYmx1ZS1mYWtlLWFjY291bnRzLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQzMCZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTQyNSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTc0MiZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD-YUE5k7brLtVIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
in November 2022, tanking the company’s stock.)

Now users will have to work harder to make sure people are who they purport to
be. I can attest that it’s harder than it sounds.

But that’s not to say Musk’s new system isn’t useful in its own way. The new
check marks have instead become an inversion of the old. If I see you have one,
I immediately don’t care what you have to say.

Times subscribers can sign up for the It Happened Online newsletter here
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/dSZa8E7z2t5qPdsmTZQQvQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmMNWYP0S9aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vbmV3c2xldHRlcnMvaWhvP2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MzAmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTE0MjUmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD0xOTg1MDI4NjUmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0xMzE3NDImdGU9MSZ1c2VyX2lkPWZhNjBjZTY2NDc3OWZmYzQyMjk1ODgxMDViZjIyOGU3VwNueXRCCmQ_mFBOZO26y7VSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].


FOR MORE

 * Clunkier and less predictable: How Musk has changed Twitter
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/Sb1go51uhnwLk0vBVzZFzQ~~/AAAAAQA~].
 * The Supreme Court agreed to decide
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/kvtYJWZ6mR2ctTWQba6KVw~~/AAAAAQA~_mFBOZO26y7VSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   whether elected officials violate the First Amendment when they block people
   on social media.

Continue reading the main story


ADVERTISEMENT

Ad
[https://liveintent.newyorktimesinfo.com/imp?s=859187&li=NN&m=fa60ce664779ffc4229588105bf228e7&p=NN_20230430]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/VY3eDejslRBXszIFW1hP0Q~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmMNWYP0SWaHR0cHM6Ly9saXZlaW50ZW50Lm5ld3lvcmt0aW1lc2luZm8uY29tL2NsaWNrP3M9ODU5MTg3JmxpPU5OJm09ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTcmcD1OTl8yMDIzMDQzMCZ0ZT0xJm5sPXRoZS1tb3JuaW5nJmVtYz1lZGl0X25uXzIwMjMwNDMwVwNueXRCCmQ_mFBOZO26y7VSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~


NEWS

Politics

 * Black voters are frustrated
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/gr2ivCAg89dY4av2-_SajA~~/AAAAAQA~_mFBOZO26y7VSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   by President Biden’s performance on issues like voting rights and police
   accountability.
 * George Mason University’s law school gained influence
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/x3NK0qFbnidadj87d4tj3w~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmMNWYP0TgaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8zMC91cy9zdXByZW1lLWNvdXJ0LXNjYWxpYS1sYXctc2Nob29sLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQzMCZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTQyNSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTc0MiZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD-YUE5k7brLtVIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
   while giving Supreme Court justices generous pay and unusual perks.
 * Donald Trump is thriving in the race
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/eavEXAUg1y7IrIgjGVnBIQ~~/AAAAAQA~_mFBOZO26y7VSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   for the 2024 Republican nomination, despite a civil rape case against him.
 * Biden made fun of Fox News and his age
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/OI-xDt0FvejgtqjMCqg8-g~~/AAAAAQA~]
   at the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner.

International

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/27/multimedia/30-the-morning-ukraine2/30-the-morning-ukraine2-jumbo.jpg]Ukrainian
soldiers taking cover.David Guttenfelder for The New York Times

 * Ukrainian soldiers are preparing for a spring offensive. The Times spent two
   weeks near the front lines hearing their stories of war
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/vV8_BxGrWGfF86PnePMYiw~~/AAAAAQA~_mFBOZO26y7VSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].
 * Hundreds of Russian men have faced criminal charges for avoiding battle
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/H88xVtSZ3fnWHYCS9y-ibw~~/AAAAAQA~].
 * Many people in Britain are more focused on navigating a cost-of-living crisis
   than celebrating King Charles III’s upcoming coronation

202760552.subject: [Outing Club] Hike Welch-Dickey Loop this Saturday!
202760552.text:
Feeling like this weekend might be too 🎀  𝒻𝒶𝓃𝒸𝓎  🎀  for your taste?
Quad Formal, Bacchanalia, Fete, stressing you out?

[image: image.png]

Come get *casual 😎 *with Arturo "socks-and-crocs" Aguilar and Kainoa
"dogs-out" Paul on *Welch-Dickey Loop* this Saturday!

[image: image.png]

*TRIP DETAILS?*
*WHO: *You. Us.
*WHAT: a 4.5 mile/1,800 ft loop hike*. According to the HOC classification
system, this is an "oak"
<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1laoQfLBWqYE2Q31rvjkLDpYWxwURWvWjy3aV87iykro/edit?usp=sharing>
hike
of moderate to high difficulty. Be prepared for a short but challenging
hike up two peaks.
*WHERE: Welch-Dickey Loop. White Mountains. New Hampshire.*
*WHEN: *We will depart the MAC parking lot at 8 am this Saturday (4/29) and
be back before the end of HUDS dinner.

*HOW: SIGN UP HERE
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfD8G77t7CPn3tBDceulz1VbPEBQu-nk9zhG69RZ8TJkMJSLQ/closedform>
BEFORE
11:59 PM WEDNESDAY*. If accepted, we have a mandatory pre-trip meeting in
the SOCH basement at 7:30 pm this Thursday (4/27).

COST: around *$30 per person for transportation + $20 HOC dues* (entitles
you to unlimited trips/free gear rentals). If someone has a car, the cost
will be significantly reduced.

HOC offers *no-questions asked financial aid* for participants, cost should
not be a barrier to join!

Reach out to kpaul@college.harvard.edu with any questions.

HOC love,
Arturo and Kainoa

_______________________________________________
The Harvard Outing Club, Inc.

To learn more about the club, upcoming trips, and how to get more involved, check out our website at http://harvardoutingclub.org or like us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/HarvardOC.

To unsubscribe send an email to outing-list-leave@lists.fas.harvard.edu
https://web.lists.fas.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/outing-list

217855687.subject: The Morning: Biden’s quiet re-election strategy
217855687.text:
[https://nl.nytimes.com/q/TWSN_qx8f4o9NziOPJd1mA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4T1PVcDbnl0QgpkPvX_SGTnsoSPUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
Plus, Harry Belafonte’s obituary.
View in browser
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/F0A-sFAK32WwxoYVSatVrA~~/AAAAAQA~_SGTnsoSPUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]|nytimes.com
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/bMlosso804Qit42sV6r2Iw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4T1P0SuaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vP2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjYmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTEwODUmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD0xOTg1MDI4NjUmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0xMzEzNzUmdGU9MSZ1c2VyX2lkPWZhNjBjZTY2NDc3OWZmYzQyMjk1ODgxMDViZjIyOGU3VwNueXRCCmQ-9f9IZOeyhI9SGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
Continue reading the main story

Marquee Ad
[https://liveintent.newyorktimesinfo.com/imp?s=859181&li=NN&m=fa60ce664779ffc4229588105bf228e7&p=NN_20230426]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/ynXvbqitsuQJOMiEGuLEjA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4T1P0SWaHR0cHM6Ly9saXZlaW50ZW50Lm5ld3lvcmt0aW1lc2luZm8uY29tL2NsaWNrP3M9ODU5MTgxJmxpPU5OJm09ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTcmcD1OTl8yMDIzMDQyNiZ0ZT0xJm5sPXRoZS1tb3JuaW5nJmVtYz1lZGl0X25uXzIwMjMwNDI2VwNueXRCCmQ-9f9IZOeyhI9SGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~

[https://static.nytimes.com/email-images/N-TheMorning%402x.png]

April 26, 2023

Author Headshot
[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/01/multimedia/David-Leonhardt-Headshot-The-Morning/David-Leonhardt-Headshot-The-Morning-blogSmallThumb-v3.png]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/jyAB5GAUNPYMbvTsCyuyxQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4T1P0TAaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZGF2aWQtbGVvbmhhcmR0P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjYmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTEwODUmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD0xOTg1MDI4NjUmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0xMzEzNzUmdGU9MSZ1c2VyX2lkPWZhNjBjZTY2NDc3OWZmYzQyMjk1ODgxMDViZjIyOGU3VwNueXRCCmQ-9f9IZOeyhI9SGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~

By David Leonhardt
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/jyAB5GAUNPYMbvTsCyuyxQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4T1P0TAaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZGF2aWQtbGVvbmhhcmR0P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjYmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTEwODUmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD0xOTg1MDI4NjUmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0xMzEzNzUmdGU9MSZ1c2VyX2lkPWZhNjBjZTY2NDc3OWZmYzQyMjk1ODgxMDViZjIyOGU3VwNueXRCCmQ-9f9IZOeyhI9SGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]

Good morning. As Biden starts his campaign, we ask why he doesn’t spend more
time in the public eye.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/25/multimedia/26themorning-lede/26themorning-lede-jumbo.jpg]President
BidenDoug Mills/The New York Times


MINIMIZING CONVERSATION 

The biggest reason that many Democratic officials are nervous about President
Biden’s age is not his ability to do the job in a second term.

Strange as it may sound, the American government can function without a healthy
president. The U.S. marched toward victory in World War II while Franklin
Roosevelt was ailing in 1944 and 1945. Four decades later, the government
managed its relationship with a teetering Soviet Union while Ronald Reagan’s
mental capacities slipped. In each case, White House aides, Cabinet secretaries
and military leaders performed well despite the lack of a fully engaged leader.

The issue that makes many Democrats even more anxious than Biden’s second-term
capabilities is whether his age will prevent him from winning a second term. If
enough voters are turned off by the idea of a president who would turn 86 in
office, Republicans might win full control of the federal government in 2024 —
and Donald Trump might return to the White House.

I know that it may seem crass for Democrats to worry more about partisan
politics than the mental acuity of the country’s most powerful person. But it’s
not entirely irrational. Today, I will look at the biggest question about
Biden’s re-election campaign — which he formally announced yesterday
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/CRK0QO3x06K68G_TzHkvug~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4T1P0TjaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vbGl2ZS8yMDIzLzAxLzIwL3VzL2JpZGVuLTIwMjQtcHJlc2lkZW50LWVsZWN0aW9uLW5ld3M_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTA4NSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTM3NSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD71_0hk57KEj1IZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
— and how he might address that question.


A GAFFE MACHINE

At 80, Biden can be an unsteady public performer. He occasionally uses the wrong
word or fails to summon a name. Some of these habits are not new, to be sure.
Biden has a stutter
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/_tnNOaojtmKtzY284NPbow~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4T1P0TpaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMi8wOC8yOS9icmllZmluZy9zdHV0dGVyaW5nLXN0aWdtYS1iaWRlbi1kaXNhYmlsaXR5Lmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTA4NSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTM3NSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD71_0hk57KEj1IZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~],
which can make it seem as if he can’t remember words when in fact he is
struggling to enunciate them. He has also long been known for saying things that
he probably shouldn’t.

“Biden living up to his gaffe-prone reputation,” read a Times headline in 2008
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ibJGFmX0rT174K-JrjJKdw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4T1P0TjaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAwOC8wOS8xMS93b3JsZC9hbWVyaWNhcy8xMWlodC1iaWRlbi40LjE2MDgxNTE1Lmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTA4NSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTM3NSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD71_0hk57KEj1IZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~],
when he was only 65. That same year, Slate magazine wrote
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/q6pVYXQcmv-60i2Ns08kBg~~/AAAAAQA~_SGTnsoSPUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
“He misspeaks so often, it’s hardly news — and hardly damaging.”

But aging does seem to have exacerbated these issues. In the upcoming campaign,
you can imagine that a verbal misstep could cause some swing voters to wonder
whether Biden is up for a second term.

These concerns help explain why polls show that roughly three-quarters of
Democratic voters approve of Biden’s performance but slightly less than half
want him to run for a second term.

Of course, there would be a simple way for Biden to address the concerns: He
could spend more time speaking in public now and demonstrate his vigor. Instead,
he and his aides have chosen the opposite approach.


THE QUIET STRATEGY

Biden has held fewer news conferences per year than any president since Reagan.
Biden gave fewer interviews during his first two years in office than any
president in even longer:

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/25/briefing/oakImage-1682455059225/oakImage-1682455059225-jumbo.png]Sources:
The American Presidency Project; Martha Joynt Kumar | By The New York Times

Michael Shear, a White House correspondent for The Times, says that Biden’s
aides are unapologetic about avoiding interviews and news conferences. “They see
these traditions as outdated and unimportant,” Michael told me. “They say that
traditional media don’t have clout, and they think that there are many other
ways that he can better present himself.”

But Biden has not replaced media conversations with other means of engaging with
the public. He does not hold regular town-hall meetings, for example. And the
statistics on interviews in the chart above include Biden’s recent conversations
with people other than journalists, like Drew Barrymore and Jason Bateman, both
actors, and Manny MUA, a YouTube beauty expert.

Biden’s strategy of minimizing unscripted public appearances suggests that his
staff believes the risk often isn’t worth the reward.


‘WATCH ME’

Biden and his aides have said that his age is a legitimate issue for debate but
that he has demonstrated he is up to the job. “The only thing I can say is,
‘Watch me,’” Biden likes to say.

There certainly are reasons to think that Biden is up for both the substantive
and performative parts of the job. He looked sharp during his State of the Union
address this year, trading verbal volleys with congressional Republicans — and
winning the exchange
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/5fHZ7ANw1uG2hHN4GcjSPg~~/AAAAAQA~_SGTnsoSPUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].
I have spoken with Biden a couple of times since he was elected and found him to
be sharp, able to discuss policy and politics in the same discursive style he
had in prior years.

He has also had a successful presidency by many measures. He passed a blizzard
of legislation, including more bipartisan bills than almost anybody expected,
and managed both the pandemic and the West’s pro-Ukraine alliance. Democrats
fared much better in the midterms than during Barack Obama’s first term or Bill
Clinton’s. As I’ve written before
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/uH6JBOgj3BHxCQVN_18BQw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4T1P0TRaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wMi8yMC9icmllZmluZy9iaWRlbi0yMDI0Lmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTA4NSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTM3NSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD71_0hk57KEj1IZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~],
Biden — unlike many other top Democrats, who have drifted to the left of most
voters — seems to understand where public opinion really is: left of center on
economic issues, more moderate on many social issues.

I can imagine a scenario in which the age worries prove overblown. Maybe voters
care less about Biden’s age than political pundits do and will re-elect him for
the same reasons they elected him: He conveys an aura of moderation and
competence when many other parts of the American political system do not. His
opponent, whether it is Trump (who’s 76) or somebody else, seems likely to
embody the Republican Party’s recent shift toward extremism.

“The man has done a good job,” Elaine Kamarck, a political scientist and
Democratic Party official recently said on The Run-Up, a Times politics podcast
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/3ctjWrHa4ct2ZxfGXWiRog~~/AAAAAQA~_SGTnsoSPUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].
“So everybody’s sort of saying, ‘Okay, yeah, he’s old. Big deal.’ There are
advantages that come with age, as well as the downsides.”

Still, a question looms: If Biden is as energetic and effective as his aides
insist, why does he spend so little time publicly engaging with other people?

A PLACE OF WONDER

Generations of children have visited the Museum of Natural History to stare at
dinosaurs, stars, or the massive blue whale hanging from the ceiling. Now the
museum is opening a new wing
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/JAiFtuu7Rj6gSpO8wB3Pzw~~/AAAAAQA~_SGTnsoSPUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
made of curving concrete and evoking the canyons of the American West.

The wing houses an insectarium and a butterfly conservatory, classrooms,
laboratories and more. Michael Kimmelman, The Times’s architecture critic,
predicts it will be an instant classic. “For a meaningful portion of its user
base, the part that hasn’t yet finished middle school,” he writes, “I expect it
will simply be, like so much else at the museum, awesome.”

Are you interested in the medical field? Are you interested in being
pre-med or pre-dental? Are you debating between the two? Hear from
several Medical
and Dental School Admissions Officers from Harvard, Tufts, and Boston
University dental and medical schools!


[image: image.png]

Time: Friday, April 28th at 3:30 pm

Location: Lowell Screening Room! (in the basement of Lowell House)


Register Here
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdAUBCZ5q_TMKOcS-5SS6fQ4SBDEZ7lv2YBIjxukXy1S_53QQ/viewform>

459231971.text:

May 1, 2023

SUPPORTED BYSUPPORTED BY logo
[https://static01.nytimes.com/ads/email_logo/Morning_briefing/us/A70]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/RGIMVzjm4rAru2UTibXftg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmMh2CP0TXaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYWJvdXRhbWF6b24uY29tL3dvcmtwbGFjZS9vdXItZW1wbG95ZWVzL2pvYi10by1jYXJlZXI_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDUwMSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTQ3OCZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTc5OSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD6CmE9kpiACylIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~

Author Headshot
[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/01/multimedia/David-Leonhardt-Headshot-The-Morning/David-Leonhardt-Headshot-The-Morning-blogSmallThumb-v3.png]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/Z01GVMZvF-42WHdG38rvNQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmMh2CP0TAaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZGF2aWQtbGVvbmhhcmR0P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA1MDEmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTE0Nzgmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD0xOTg1MDI4NjUmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0xMzE3OTkmdGU9MSZ1c2VyX2lkPWZhNjBjZTY2NDc3OWZmYzQyMjk1ODgxMDViZjIyOGU3VwNueXRCCmQ-gphPZKYgAspSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~

By David Leonhardt
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/Z01GVMZvF-42WHdG38rvNQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmMh2CP0TAaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZGF2aWQtbGVvbmhhcmR0P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA1MDEmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTE0Nzgmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD0xOTg1MDI4NjUmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0xMzE3OTkmdGU9MSZ1c2VyX2lkPWZhNjBjZTY2NDc3OWZmYzQyMjk1ODgxMDViZjIyOGU3VwNueXRCCmQ-gphPZKYgAspSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]

Good morning. If there were an affirmative action program for the descendants of
enslaved people, would you consider that to be race-based?



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/05/01/multimedia/01themorning-lede-pmft/01themorning-lede-pmft-jumbo.jpg]The
Supreme Court.Shuran Huang for The New York Times


NOT SO SIMPLE

During oral arguments for the biggest Supreme Court cases, the justices’
questions are often pointed, meant to advance their own view of the case.
Conservative justices ask friendly questions of lawyers on the conservative side
and burrow into the logical weaknesses
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/NjAfYEogC5WOITHtCvZH9Q~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmMh2CP0TGaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAwOS8wNS8yNi91cy8yNmJhci5odG1sP2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA1MDEmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTE0Nzgmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD0xOTg1MDI4NjUmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0xMzE3OTkmdGU9MSZ1c2VyX2lkPWZhNjBjZTY2NDc3OWZmYzQyMjk1ODgxMDViZjIyOGU3VwNueXRCCmQ-gphPZKYgAspSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
of the liberal side. Liberal justices do the opposite.

The five hours of oral arguments on two affirmative action cases in October
mostly fit this pattern. But, about three hours into the session, Justice Brett
Kavanaugh asked a less typical question. It involved slavery, and it raised an
inconvenient issue for Kavanaugh’s fellow conservatives.

“So today, a benefit to descendants of slaves would not be race-based, correct?”
Kavanaugh said to Cameron Norris, a lawyer arguing for the end of race-based
affirmative action.

Norris seemed caught off guard. “I — I think that’s incorrect, Justice
Kavanaugh,” he said.

Kavanaugh then noted that Norris had already acknowledged that the post-Civil
War benefits that formerly enslaved people received from the federal government
were not race-based. Those benefits were based on their status as having been
enslaved, not their skin color.

“If that’s correct, then the benefit for descendants of former slaves is also
not race-based,” Kavanaugh said. “You can make other arguments if you want about
that, but it does not seem to be race-based.”

The conversation quickly moved on (partly because Justice Neil Gorsuch, another
conservative, moved it along). But the exchange highlighted a tension that’s
likely to be central to the debate over affirmative action after the Supreme
Court rules. Put simply, getting rid of race-based admissions policies may turn
out to be harder than it sounds.

Today’s newsletter is the first in what will be an occasional series on the
future of affirmative action. I welcome reader questions and suggestions via
email at themorning@nytimes.com [themorning@nytimes.com].


GRIT AND CHARACTER

The court is expected to rule on affirmative action in June, and observers
expect tight restrictions on race-based considerations
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/7jJmhBLvG1FPhA5PCouX8Q~~/AAAAAQA~-gphPZKYgAspSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
in college admissions. The six Republican-appointed justices, including
Kavanaugh, all seem opposed to the status quo, in which many colleges have
different admissions criteria for different racial groups. Black, Latino and
Native American applicants are now admitted with lower test scores and grades
than Asian and white applicants.

But even most opponents of the current system agree that colleges should take
into account some parts of an applicant’s background. Consider two teenagers:
One grew up with working-class parents, attended a high-poverty high school and
scored 1390 on the SAT. The other went to an elite private high school, took SAT
prep classes and scored 1400. Surely, the 1390 is more impressive.

When a person has overcome hardship, as Patrick Strawbridge, another lawyer
opposing racial preferences, said to the justices, “it tells you something about
the character and experience of the applicant other than their skin color.”

Opponents of today’s affirmative action have tried to draw a clean distinction
between racial and nonracial considerations, and the opponents are correct that
colleges now use race itself as a major factor. But if the court bars that
practice, colleges are likely to become more aggressive about using measures of
socioeconomic disadvantage. And that’s where the situation could get tricky.
Many socioeconomic measures, after all, are strongly correlated with race.


LEGACY AT U.N.C.

Kavanaugh’s question about slavery was jarring because the overlap was complete:
An admissions policy based on a family’s history of enslavement certainly sounds
like a race-based policy, without being one on paper.

Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson pointed out another example during oral arguments:
For a long time universities, including public schools like the University of
North Carolina, refused to enroll Black students. Jackson compared a
hypothetical applicant who would be a fifth-generation U.N.C. student — and thus
receive the so-called legacy boost — with an applicant whose family had lived in
the state just as long but whose ancestors had been barred from attending. As
Jackson asked, shouldn’t the second applicant receive a boost, too?

Both Jackson’s and Kavanaugh’s hypotheticals might seem narrow, involving
discrimination that occurred long ago. But the practical questions are broader.
Because of the deep racial inequities in the U.S. — caused partly by government
policies like whites-only housing subsidies
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/NFYP0MX2D7lhcwYn-xgXtQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmMh2CP0T1aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAxNy8wOC8yNC91cHNob3QvaG93LXJlZGxpbmluZ3MtcmFjaXN0LWVmZmVjdHMtbGFzdGVkLWZvci1kZWNhZGVzLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDUwMSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTQ3OCZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTc5OSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD6CmE9kpiACylIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
— many admission criteria based on economic disadvantage would apply
disproportionately to applicants of color, especially Black applicants.

One example would be an admissions policy that gave extra consideration to a
student who grew up in a family with a net worth of less than $30,000. Most
Black households fall into that category; only a small share of white households
do. There are even greater racial disparities in measures based on neighborhood
wealth.

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/29/briefing/oakImage-1682797981402/oakImage-1682797981402-jumbo.png]Source:
The Federal Reserve | By The New York Times

I’m not suggesting that criteria like these are merely dressed-up versions of
today’s system. To many people, they’re more justifiable because they can apply
to disadvantaged members of all races. (Here’s a Times profile of Richard
Kahlenberg
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/WTKjYuyxWJXXas_je1ECzg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmMh2CP0TmaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wMy8yOS91cy9yaWNoYXJkLWthaGxlbmJlcmctYWZmaXJtYXRpdmUtYWN0aW9uLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDUwMSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTQ3OCZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTc5OSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD6CmE9kpiACylIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~],
a researcher who makes that case, arguing for a new class-based system.)

Still, the legal fights will not end with a Supreme Court decision. Adam Liptak,
who covers the court for The Times, says that he expects a flurry of lawsuits
over what constitutes a race-based admissions policy in disguise versus a
class-based policy that happens to affect different races differently.

As with abortion, a Supreme Court ruling will reshape the political debate
without ending it.

Is your podcast queue empty? I enjoyed listening to the oral arguments on
affirmative action, starting here
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/al0GRN35BLiRDayMV5sMFg~~/AAAAAQA~]
and continuing here
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/tz0nyNfZj0CuDw0Nxte8dQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmMh2CP0TUaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuc3VwcmVtZWNvdXJ0Lmdvdi9vcmFsX2FyZ3VtZW50cy9hdWRpby8yMDIyLzIwLTExOTk_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDUwMSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTQ3OCZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTc5OSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD6CmE9kpiACylIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~].

Continue reading the main story


A MESSAGE FROM AMAZON

[https://static01.nytimes.com/ads/email_logo/Morning_briefing/us/NYT-600x600-jessica.png]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/RGIMVzjm4rAru2UTibXftg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmMh2CP0TXaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYWJvdXRhbWF6b24uY29tL3dvcmtwbGFjZS9vdXItZW1wbG95ZWVzL2pvYi10by1jYXJlZXI_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDUwMSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTQ3OCZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTc5OSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD6CmE9kpiACylIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~

EMBRACING CURLS, AGAIN

The perm is making a comeback
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/FP1HbfdgBPgIK2TK9n4FVw~~/AAAAAQA~].
But the hairstyle has changed a lot since its 1980s heyday: Instead of tight
curls and loads of hair spray, the modern perm is tender and loose.

The style has long been popular in South Korea, but has grown globally since the
early 2000s as Korean pop culture became more influential in the West. “I love
my curls. I feel so much more self-confident,” Brendan Noji, 25, told The Times.
“The waves add a lot more personality that feels a lot closer to my own.”

607936505.subject: [cs-undergrads] GPT-4 - How does it work, and how do I build apps with it?
607936505.text:
Hi all,

Perhaps of interest, a lunchtime lecture on GPT-4 next Monday! RSVP at
https://forms.gle/GGniJDH4wAWG7Ca67.

djm

---

First software ate the world. Now Generative AI is eating software. Join us
for a three-piece lecture on theory, practice, and Otto's pizza.

*GPT-4 - How does it work, and how do I build apps with it?*
Monday, May 1, 2023, 12pm–1:30pm
1 Brattle Square <https://goo.gl/maps/4ad3BCzXbqEAunPj9> #204, roughly
across from Felipe's

RSVP at https://forms.gle/GGniJDH4wAWG7Ca67.

First, you’ll learn how GPT-4 works and why human language turns out to
play such a critical role in computing. Next, you’ll see how AI-native
software is being made. Every attendee will leave with AI know-how, a full
belly from pizza, and free credits on Steamship — the hosting platform for
AI apps.

Taught by Ted Benson, founder of Steamship, MIT Ph.D., & Y Combinator Alum;
and Sil Hamilton, researcher of emergent AI behavior at McGill University.

This event is open to anyone at Harvard, whether taking CS50 or not!

-- 
You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "cs-undergrads" group.
To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to cs-undergrads+unsubscribe@seas.harvard.edu.

675082102.subject: [Bacch-talk]  Summer Roommate for Apartment Rental from Harvard
675082102.text:
Hey,
I'm looking for roommates to rent an apartment at 10 or 20 DeWolfe St from
Harvard.

*Skip this paragraph if you read the email Harvard sent out:*
The license period is from *June 9 to August 14* (10 weeks) and is
non-negotiable. There is an optional separate meal plan ($1980), but the
rooms include a kitchen. It's 2 bedrooms (with 2 beds each) and 1 bath.
It's $6,360 for the room regardless of how many roommates there are, but
the room can house up to 4 people* (with 4 people, that's $640 a month per
person).*

I'm a dude but fine with roommates of any gender. I'll be doing ML/controls
research at Harvard over the summer, and I'm from Boston. *Please let me
know asap if you're interested; the deadline to apply is next Friday
morning. Please also forward to anyone who might be interested.*
Thanks,
Christy

676810845.subject: Time Reporting Deadline
676810845.text:
To all time reporting staff:

Time Reporting for this week (04/23/23 - 04/29/23) must be completed by 5PM, Thursday, April 27, 2023.

If you have an approved flexwork arrangement in another Harvard registered payroll state and updated your tax residence, distribution and forms in PeopleSoft, you may now enter time for the other state(s). Remember you only need to enter a state when you are not working in your “default” state. 

See Entering Time for Overtime Eligible Employees at https://oc.finance.harvard.edu/employees-working-outside-of-massachusetts 


These deadlines are system-wide deadlines.  If local policies or procedures dictate that you must report time by an earlier deadline, please follow the local policy.

If your department has instructed you to fill out a paper timesheet, disregard this notice.

If you are a student trying to report Work Study and cannot do so, please see your local HR representative.

PeopleSoft is accessed at: https://peoplesoft.harvard.edu

Note - if you do not have a HarvardKey, you can obtain one by going to https://key.harvard.edu.

Please do not reply to this email. If you have any questions, please contact the help desk at 5-7777 or your local HR Office.

Thank you.


Need instructions on time reporting in PeopleSoft 9.2? Click here for a detailed work instruction:   
https://trainingportal.harvard.edu/Saba/Web_spf/NA1PRD0068/common/resources/resourcedetail/simrs000000000003264

Visit the Employee and Manager Group to view a complete set of Self Service and Manager Self Service work instructions:
https://trainingportal.harvard.edu/Saba/Web_spf/NA1PRD0068/common/groupdetai//teams000000000002861

894916368.text:
HGSU-UAW Local 5118: a union of student workers at Harvard University
[https://actionnetwork.org/unlayer_files/1606249874824-HGSU-UAW+email+banner+2.png]
harvardgradunion.org?link_id=1&can_id=2017376a1ff0b9d14a923be5d6734d60&source=email-hsgu-student-worker-news-student-labor-union-2&email_referrer=email_1900151&email_subject=hsgu-student-worker-news-student-labor-union

 

You are receiving this email because you are currently working in a position
covered by a labor contract between the University and the Harvard Graduate
Student Union-United Auto Workers Local 5118 (HGSU-UAW) and you are not yet a
member of your union. All student workers need to make a choice regarding their

and we will contact you to answer any questions you have!

 

Report a Workplace Issue
[https://url1005.email.actionnetwork.org/ss/c/mw31GZsW-tYdpIw-ePlYv02f5UDMJYkaa9RiRvU57fRu50VdoLZichlgJqIYdpBykeiBoFhXDL9C17ufa_6wN0LUiXWnSNoCPDbAaJni8npxUh_Sd92Dgj4GcnBpC5xwYOLz2nrU4QIfM4xm-Jj8I4RSAxmAar4GCTuY76q59mKRB9xoxTT-f75zwOp9qSAoQnDBOCE_5wS0jiVZaGvqDPeU490BHF2PbCvkt1rf1oRMoCSkKRpzR-NN9-38bLgIh-52vB_VJ3-FoBRFyPWRCrWszJog_UQZEnD4cOU5i8mos2IcePulOprvSoFA4wipuso11KsR-9yex-Ln6Y30tg/3vt/I31uxXW6Q4umryEbEsxgWQ/h2/ff3SFCiEbvQdqWJIMmlsweRDFE4lG-OikIDhO3ThPUU]

 

 

HEALTHCARE, DENTAL, AND CHILDCARE FUND APPLICATIONS OPEN

 

Healthcare, Dental, and Childcare Fund applications have re-opened for the
spring round of funding from April 11. This is the last chance to apply for
reimbursement from these funds in the current contract year.

 

These funds are meant to offset the cost of healthcare, dental care (including
Dental Blue premiums), and childcare for student workers in HGSU-UAW eligible
positions.

 

Applications are due on May 9, 2023. Follow the button links to apply. For more
information on the benefit funds and what you can get reimbursed, visit our
website at https://harvardgradunion.org/benefits/.

DEMAND A LIVING WAGE!

 

Harvard accepted a $300 million donation from billionaire hedge fund manager and
GOP mega donor
[https://url1005.email.actionnetwork.org/ss/c/atcYNHk4Eh2YdGnwBh-YDL0195r-gNaKL0NXw0E6jsaBPJHbatLS9oqm9g34wigEJIEoaQje18PMLvn185hUUyfQCKapCm5OsEzR-XBgb3J60ra6B-1g5Qf9lEY9XHHfI1GBPjs2ehfLpVInHxYR2uohzX_PiuCVcFE-v7cnskgbwZar9kkcH5P43WjvnqTn06ELcBH7a7RARW8cHxfaM7yGTwcjllr3uBakQPzKV3HMNmRkhFC9pQvDseEHGHKEXIcoygdcSFq92idlR1wyGlSQbt5aUXHWbCE42OHkz2PV5pjV5fh67T8pYz9KyDcQsAjO-wuE7zBIheyGn8cd7102c3IWLGbYPt1U-ieW2yiwV_oOb72Mkj8LckGKHLSwnpKYalS03hsfDQYZNZV70g/3vt/I31uxXW6Q4umryEbEsxgWQ/h6/U_9PYwixKP7t2lEDG1JUqbZXN-8vnxa0s3S0hwFkZTw]
Ken Griffin and renamed the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences after him in
exchange. Meanwhile, Harvard ran a seminar for graduate students to apply for
food stamps
[https://url1005.email.actionnetwork.org/ss/c/atcYNHk4Eh2YdGnwBh-YDDaoH_YJmZr3EvCbTx-WNe2kmhlZBS8_y85_s2Ah3XSOIPhZo9XoPQJsbktMJGWIdC1lXncVsrEaGJZxpfhahuxS2veFdhyDSSpomLiAFH8_cSJSEjKpvp8YaA0effFYPySao8vBSsFlZf0V5heUonF08iMlRl1xRHMnCQx3JrES3KO9ryLNNE1X2y-j5nEzkk6aKmJzZ38-K2CdBufF0Tm2KzIM1U8M1aoCmBtusmQS_IRGjzvDL-48GvKGlAOf3kqcCbt9P-eMsU6au4ADO1w41g5sK1m4YgNMue_gxs_HGteH-qkh9OesmRwf-Cz6rFUzXgChjbvBhqYTAm2c9zgC_JvIEwiBLYX-YYvmnxigp-Iut4KviLgxiVMbQDEyKiYfF-2fzAx5ZHluj4Aq7ISfrJ59prI80qAs2mvNnPURmNgHcIKdzbZuqGdtabOTLQ/3vt/I31uxXW6Q4umryEbEsxgWQ/h7/oAX0Y1OLMVL00DHYmdJ9Kn4yc3UqGvW0DBSZpp1eFN8]
and Harvard housing raised rents in student housing by 6%. Further, we are
currently experiencing the highest inflation rates in over 40 years.

 

We are starting a campaign to urge that, effective July 1 2023, Harvard bring
all student research and teaching salaries up to the living wage for Middlesex
County
[https://url1005.email.actionnetwork.org/ss/c/nIATlT34azO8Uq6tATWtxDLsBLVa33FW-KSgwmF2Tj8_kQ-De9J7r9igGp2-Z5-ENnyOl5LIss6WOJK_OYo0BOXxpoW0AfchlJMc9t1oEKZxlrz1oavTHUTRBYT5kgr60JpoN7MfgOGcTPFoBdt4aZGk71xy30ao-mLv28uGnDD82jnNiUpXLxHaJz1jSUBvj6xJjdquGnjwqI3hvYzt4mBZA54DE4OO-JeOtWG1DU-rxyfntWYea_lApsT0oUUafsmiaLi0Crhm8EczJAOYlseIgoM43IaZLFPfgHFZ1mv4iuEa8RUp_jW3LR6aXrf2IYuphaehVwaGgfmIdgpXeg/3vt/I31uxXW6Q4umryEbEsxgWQ/h8/dY5ml7jKIZ7JKdStlp3OCYEtlczeJGEzLgWyCQpFVGI],
of $48,779 per year for salaried employees and $23.45 per hour for hourly
employees. We have to fight for a living wage and union protections! Start here
by signing this petition and coming to our living wage rally on May 10th at 12
p.m. in the Harvard Yard.

936457503.subject: [cs-undergrads] CS Grad School Info and Thesis Panel: Monday and Tuesday 11am
936457503.text:
Dear CS,

CS is hosting two events next week during reading period. Learn more about Grad School and Writing a thesis!

Grad School Information Session:
Learn what it means to go to Grad School for a PhD, and what you need to apply
Monday May 1st at 11am
via Zoom https://harvard.zoom.us/j/97310334858?pwd=MUtIVE1pQU5MRnFyelR6NGZQUlhtZz09&from=addon

Thesis Panel Information Session:
Hear from some of our thesis writers and learn the general timeline of writing a thesis.
Donuts and coffee provided
Tuesday May 2nd at 11am in SEC 3.302&3.303

Beth Musser

Undergraduate Program Coordinator for Computer Science
Office of Academic Programs, SEC 1.101-03
Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Tel: (617) 496-0789
Remote: Mon/Thur, In-office: Tues/Wed/Fri
She/her/hers
[cid:image001.jpg@01D9784C.C7C78690]

1002615813.subject: [Bacch-talk]  Fwd: Register for Center for International Development's Career Event! [BCG, Microsoft]
1002615813.text:
[image: HARVARD Kennedy School | Center for International Development]
<https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=3786aad9eaecc33f0600b04efafa49320ac0dc1101a135dd62dfdb6afa909ddd399caeaea0403abbe1997834d617c36750c6d3c81f2990fc1fd58720872ff8b9>



*UNDERGRADUATE OPPORTUNITIES*




Career Roundtable





[image: imgonline-com-ua-twotoone-7zvQoQbNWJ5dMo.jpeg]



International Development Career Panel with Samira Khan and Qahir Dhanani

*Date: *May 1, 2023
*Time: *2:45PM - 4PM ET
*Location: *Wex-434A.B Conference Room

*Speakers*:
Samira Khan, Director of Field & Campaign Insights, Global Public Affairs,
Microsoft

Qahir Dhanani, Partner & Associate Director, Boston Consulting Group

CID is pleased to invite Samira Khan and Qahir Dhanani, two leading experts
in addressing global development issues, to come speak about their
experiences. The roundtable chat is geared towards providing career advice
for undergraduate students interested in international development as they
seek to find opportunities in the field for internships or post-graduation
careers.

*About Samira Khan*
Samira Khan is a social impact innovator and intrapreneur with a passion
for empathy-driven solutions that promote societal well-being and address
global challenges. With 15 years of experience across sectors, she
currently serves as a director within Global Public Affairs at Microsoft,
having previously worked at the intersection of social innovation and
technology at Microsoft and Salesforce.

Samira is committed to empowering people through entrepreneurship,
innovation, and creative partnerships that span regions and socioeconomic
lines. She focuses on fostering transparent access to knowledge and
cross-pollination of ideas to drive capital commitments towards the SDGs,
sustainability, and well-being technology. Her work targets vulnerable
communities, particularly Black and Brown populations in the US, Asia, and
emerging markets.

*About Qahir Dhanani*

Qahir Dhanani is a Partner & Associate Director at the Boston Consulting
Group (BCG), where he plays a central role in the firm's leadership team
focused on global economic and social development. With over 15 years of
experience, Qahir has advised senior executives and officials across
public, private, and social sectors on policy and programmatic issues,
including climate action, poverty alleviation, jobs, competitiveness,
infrastructure, innovation, and entrepreneurship. His expertise also
extends to operational matters such as agile, organizational
transformation, process excellence, change management, and leadership
development.

Before joining BCG, Qahir served as an Advisor to the CEO at the World Bank
and held various positions within the Aga Khan Development Network,
showcasing his commitment to driving positive change in global communities

Members of the Harvard Community can register for a career chat roundtable
with Samira and Qahir. Please RSVP via the link here for this event.



*Register for roundtable with Samira and Qahir
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScimNHRZH0xzJPKcX0vc9imCP-OpKyZtVTGVLMLg0M_FPaxyg/viewform?usp=sf_link>*



*Center for International Development at Harvard University*

*Harvard Kennedy School*

79 John F. Kennedy Street Cambridge, MA 02138 USA

1100815398.text:
Schedule your photosittings now!
Dear Class of 2024,

To ensure that you have a photo in the Class of 2024 yearbook, please schedule a photositting appointment as soon as possible. Although there will be sessions during the fall, the dates have not been confirmed, and we will not be able to accommodate everyone in the fall due to the large student size.

Book now on our website through this link here. (https://harvardyearbook.com/forms/photosittings)

Please respond to this email or send us an email at inquiries@harvardyearbook.com if you have any questions.
Best wishes,
Harvard Yearbook Publications

1205871746.subject: TODAY: Economics Research Poster Session!
1205871746.text:
Calling all Ec Concentrators!

We hope you’re able to join us for the inaugural Undergraduate Conference Highlighting Excellence in Economics Research (U-CHEER) TODAY!
Join the Economics Department in celebrating research by Economics Senior Thesis Writers, SUPER* Research Assistants, and Ec 970 students at the U-CHEER Poster Session.

U-CHEER Poster Session
11am-1pm
TODAY, Thurs, April 27
Littauer Third Floor Lounge
Hot lunch provided

Enjoy some delicious food while you peruse presentations of our fabulous students’ research on education, development, finance, political economy, health, social programs, labor markets, and more!

You can also explore past and present ec senior theses on the Ec Thesis Blog: http://blogs.harvard.edu/econthesis/

All Ec and Ec-interested students are warmly invited to join us at U-CHEER and learn about the many exciting ways to pursue ec research.  We hope to see you there!

Best wishes,
Your Ec Advising Team

*SUPER = Semester Undergraduate Program for Economics Research :)


_______________________________________________
Juniors-econ-list mailing list -- juniors-econ-list@lists.fas.harvard.edu
To unsubscribe send an email to juniors-econ-list-leave@lists.fas.harvard.edu

1272432870.text:
Who will preserve our history once we make it?

The Black Arts Collective presents…

IN THE SHADOW OF GIANTS

TOMORROW, APRIL 27TH AT 6PM

HARVARD COMMONS, SMITH CENTER

1350 MASS. AVE, CAMBRIDGE, MA

Free admission and open to the public.

[image: image.png]

DON’T FOLD ON OUR BIGGEST EVENT YET!

1568497810.subject: [Bacch-talk]  GET PAID TO PARTICIPATE IN STUDY ON AI ASSISTANCE
1568497810.text:
We invite you to participate in a research study conducted by a team of
undergraduate/graduate researchers at MIT Media Lab.

The purpose of this study is to investigate the impact of our system on
critical thinking. Our system passively listens to a conversation between a
user and an interviewer where the user is invited to complete a series of
critical thinking assessments. The user is able to utilize AI assistance in
completing these tasks by prompting an AI assistant with eye gaze, which
then displays the assistance in real time augmented reality. The goal of
this system is passive, real-time integration of human and artificial
intelligence.

During the study (~70min), you will complete a series of questions,
utilizing one of the world’s most advanced commercial AR headsets (HoloLens
2), that costs $3500. Study Dates: 4/28-4/30.

You will then participate in a post-study survey. Study participants will
receive a $20 worth gift card after the research. Please sign up here
<https://forms.gle/t2wfVE2Abj4AGEui8> to participate!

If you have any questions, contact:

Alina Yu, alinayu@college.harvard.edu

Anhphu Nguyen, anguyen1@college.harvard.edu
[image: image.png] [image: image.png]

1680953364.subject: [Outing Club] WE WANT YOU! BIKE THE MINUTEMAN TRAIL WITH US THIS FRIDAY!
1680953364.text:
Hey YOU!

Are you looking to serve your colony and fight for no taxation without
representation? Have you dreamt of bringing glory to your people and
fighting against the tyranny of British imperialism?  Can you be ready at a
minute’s notice to stand for your principles and ideals? Did you know you
can accomplish this all (and your exams!!) during reading week by biking
the beautiful Minuteman bike trail? Join Ezra “Paul Revere” Feder and
Gunnhildur “Who’s Paul Revere?” Hallgrimsdottir for a bike ride along the
Minuteman Trail!


If you are looking for the small print of this legal agreement….

So what are we doing?

Trail name: Minuteman Bike Trail

Length: 20 miles, ~3.5 hours on a flat paved bike road alongside pretty
greenery.

Difficulty: Oak according to HOC’s trip classification system
<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1laoQfLBWqYE2Q31rvjkLDpYWxwURWvWjy3aV87iykro/edit>.
This will be a good leg workout, but the road is nice and flat. We
especially advise against using Bluebikes for this trip, and advise you to
try borrowing a bike from that friend that has class in the SEC.

When will this pilgrimage of liberty be taken?

Date and time: 4/28, 9am-1pm

Location: We’ll start and end at the MAC parking lot

Mandatory Pre-Trip Meeting: 4/27, 4-5pm, location TBD

How do I join?

Just fill out this form <https://forms.gle/hJxrZa6NRYjiRyFo8> by 5pm on
4/26. You are responsible for obtaining your own bike.

Cost:

If you own a bike and a HOC membership, this trip will be free for you. A
HOC membership dues are $20 and last for 6 months, allowing access to all
HOC trips and gear rentals. As always, HOC offers a no-questions-asked
financial aid policy, cost should never be a barrier for joining our trip!

If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to reach out to
ghallgrimsdottir@college.harvard.edu or ezrafeder@college.harvard.edu.

Bonus for scrolling so far: a photo of Ezra and Gunnhildur in action on the
trail twenty years from now!


With HOC love,

Ezra and Gunnhildur

_______________________________________________
The Harvard Outing Club, Inc.

To learn more about the club, upcoming trips, and how to get more involved, check out our website at http://harvardoutingclub.org or like us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/HarvardOC.

To unsubscribe send an email to outing-list-leave@lists.fas.harvard.edu
https://web.lists.fas.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/outing-list

1733549413.subject: [Bacch-talk]  Last Film Club Screening // THE BIG LEBOWSKI // Sever 113, 4:30 p.m. Friday (Pizza)
1733549413.text:
Hey Lowell,

Film Club has their last screening of the semester. Sadly, it won't be in
the Screening Room this time, but it'd still be nice to have some of you
there (there will be Domino's!)! Also, if anybody has anything that they'd
like to see Film Club show in the Screening Room next semester, let me
know! Details below (this movie is *soooooo* good):

-- 

Happy last day of class,

This Friday is the last Film Club screening of the semester :(. To finish
things off, we'll be watching the Coen Brothers' 1998 crime comedy classic *The
Big Lebowski*! This movie has all the thrills: kidnapping, mistaken
identity, nihilists, ferrets, millionaires and doobie-rollin slackers, and,
of course, lots and lots of bowling (also maybe the second coming of *Jesus*).
It is also one of the most outrageously hilarious movies out there, so come
if you are looking for some laughs to brighten up your Reading Week.

Film Club will meet in **Sever 113** this *Friday* (4/28) at **4:30
p.m.** There
will be *PIZZA* and drinks!

[image: The Dude at 20: fascinating facts about the legendary film The Big
Lebowski | CBC Radio]

Best,
Aidin K

-101430315.subject: [Bacch-talk]  HRO and the Harvard Choruses Present Verdi's Requiem!
-101430315.text:
[https://cdn-images.mailchimp.com/template_images/gallery/47662b23-df38-45d4-8005-9b2f50193f4b.png]

[https://mcusercontent.com/f3b590b690480b106f3d5855b/images/7712557f-8b85-48df-4ff6-e3a7d81bccb8.png]

 


HARVARD-RADCLIFFE ORCHESTRA AND 
THE HARVARD CHORUSES PRESENT...

VERDI'S REQUIEM

 


IN CONJUNCTION WITH FEATURED SOLOISTS

[https://mcusercontent.com/f3b590b690480b106f3d5855b/images/526b52d3-8587-b413-576e-e92454e4af53.png]

Join the Harvard-Radcliffe Orchestra and the Harvard Choruses (Harvard Glee
Club, Radcliffe Choral Society, Harvard-Radcliffe Collegium Musicum) for a
monumental performance of Verdi’s Requiem on Sunday, April 30th at 3 PM in
Sanders Theater! Under the baton of HRO Music Director Federico Cortese, 250
Harvard students will perform alongside world-renowned soloists Raquel Gonzalez
(Soprano), Renee Tatum (Mezzo-Soprano), Cooper Nolan (Tenor), and Weston Hurt
(Bass). We’re so excited to welcome you to Sanders Theatre! 

Tickets are $10 for Harvard Students with HUID and $30 for General Admission.
You can buy them at the Box Office or from any HRO or Harvard Choruses member.
VIP Preferred Seating ($50) in Center Mezzanine and Center Balcony is also

-1345581983.subject: [Bacch-talk]  Sign Up for Futsal Tournament Tomorrow!
-1345581983.text:
Forwarding for a friend-


Futsal (Indoor Soccer) Club is running its 4th FUTSAL TOURNAMENT *TOMORROW
(* Wednesday 2/25) from 5-7pm at the QRAC!

The tournament will only have knockout rounds.

We will reimburse the top 3 teams with Felipe’s/Jefe’s, Domino’s, and Kung
Fu Tea!

Like last time, teams (of 5) will be completely random, and the brackets as
well as the exact length of the rounds will be determined later (Likely 5
minute halves with 1 minute rest in between) .

You have the option to sign up with a partner.

There are a few important details with this step:

   1.

   You will likely be with a partner on a team, but the other 3 members
   will be randomly assigned)
   2.

   Furthermore, you must BOTH SIGN UP and indicate your partner preference
   (if only one person signs up indicating their partner only the person who
   signed up will get to play).
   3.

   This is only guaranteed as long as spots for pairs are available, which
   means that if you sign up late with a partner, you will likely be split
   apart regardless (and whichever partner signs up first will have priority
   in actually getting to play)


If you would like to participate, please fill out this google form:
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfDDyd_TIzIbWRb4DZVPLBtj5LWpWP22YyIuf8M1NCX_PBVpQ/viewform?usp=sf_link

Please make sure that you are logged in to your browser with your Harvard
email before accessing the form (and let me know if you have any issues).

Sign-ups are first come first serve and we have 40 spots available.

Spots 41-46 will be alternates.

Thanks and hope to see you there!

--

-281534408.subject: The Morning: Tucker Carlson’s downfall
-281534408.text:
[https://nl.nytimes.com/q/0q88sCQlEZ0Rrm3YvIi2Iw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjUTPVcDbnl0QgpkPhOwR2T_P3JfUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
Plus, President Biden’s campaign announcement.
View in browser
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/B7lCLDWw-np0K1pvWdvJXw~~/AAAAAQA~_P3JfUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]|nytimes.com
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/c8P-QERa5AbPfuF9WR2Rgg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjUTP0SuaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vP2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjUmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTEwMDMmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD0xOTg1MDI4NjUmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0xMzEyOTAmdGU9MSZ1c2VyX2lkPWZhNjBjZTY2NDc3OWZmYzQyMjk1ODgxMDViZjIyOGU3VwNueXRCCmQ-E7BHZP8_cl9SGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
[https://static.nytimes.com/email-images/N-TheMorning%402x.png]

April 25, 2023

Continue reading the main story

SUPPORTED BY GE Aerospace [ge.com]

Author Headshot
[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2022/01/13/reader-center/author-german-lopez/author-german-lopez-blogSmallThumb-v2.png]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/cJ7f2W8uA7_1p6t-uUXABA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjUTP0S9aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZ2VybWFuLWxvcGV6P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjUmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTEwMDMmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD0xOTg1MDI4NjUmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0xMzEyOTAmdGU9MSZ1c2VyX2lkPWZhNjBjZTY2NDc3OWZmYzQyMjk1ODgxMDViZjIyOGU3VwNueXRCCmQ-E7BHZP8_cl9SGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~

By German Lopez
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/cJ7f2W8uA7_1p6t-uUXABA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjUTP0S9aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZ2VybWFuLWxvcGV6P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjUmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTEwMDMmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD0xOTg1MDI4NjUmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0xMzEyOTAmdGU9MSZ1c2VyX2lkPWZhNjBjZTY2NDc3OWZmYzQyMjk1ODgxMDViZjIyOGU3VwNueXRCCmQ-E7BHZP8_cl9SGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]

Good morning. Tucker Carlson is out at Fox News. Plus, President Biden announced
his campaign for re-election.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/25/multimedia/25themorning-lede-carlson-vfqp/25themorning-lede-carlson-vfqp-jumbo.jpg]Tucker
CarlsonLeigh Vogel for The New York Times


CANCELED

For years, the Fox News host Tucker Carlson has faced criticisms of his
amplification of racist and anti-immigrant ideas. But those issues seemed to
have little to do with his demise.

Instead, a growing list of controversies related to Carlson’s conduct on and off
the air had begun to aggravate Fox News executives, and the network abruptly
announced his departure yesterday
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/A8AsBFMOoJ0SKEvmts2b9Q~~/AAAAAQA~_P3JfUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].

Network leaders and contributors had complained, and some quit, over Carlson’s
misleading coverage of the Jan. 6 attacks, in which he depicted rioters as
“mostly peaceful” onlookers. His coverage of 2020 election conspiracy theories
was part of Dominion Voting Systems’ lawsuit against Fox
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/JIuXxsTN8PPe5hq55tAnvg~~/AAAAAQA~-E7BHZP8_cl9SGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~],
which the network settled last week. Carlson had also privately denigrated Fox
executives, saying they had cost the network credibility by allowing it to call
President Biden’s election victory, as The Washington Post reported
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/ZXIloSb32su_AYq23nfX0A~~/AAAAAQA~_P3JfUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].

And a former producer recently accused Carlson in a lawsuit of overseeing a
misogynistic and discriminatory workplace. Fox has disputed her claims.

As one of the top hosts on the most watched cable news network, Carlson played
an outsize role in conservative politics. Today’s newsletter will look at
Carlson’s influence and what his exit means for Fox News.


A BIG AUDIENCE

Carlson took over Fox News’s prized 8 p.m. slot in 2017 and increased its
already-high ratings, quickly becoming a fixture on the right-wing network and
in conservative politics.

How? Carlson tapped into
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/tP2ES3N0yjZjPoszfzmj5Q~~/AAAAAQA~_P3JfUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
white viewers’ fears over the country’s changing racial demographics, which
fueled Donald Trump’s rise in the 2016 election. He would regularly focus on the
notion of the “great replacement,” a racist conspiracy theory that claims elites
are importing supposedly obedient immigrants to disempower native-born
Americans. In 2018, Carlson argued that hordes of immigrants were making America
“poorer and dirtier.”

Carlson often highlighted local news stories but twisted them to make broader
claims about Americans losing control of their country. In one segment in 2017,
he claimed “Gypsies” were causing chaos in a small Pennsylvania town, urinating
and defecating in the streets.

“The message of these segments was always the same: You and your way of life are
under attack, and the people doing the attacking look different and have
different values than you do,” my colleague Nicholas Confessore, who covered
Carlson’s rise for The Times
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/tP2ES3N0yjZjPoszfzmj5Q~~/AAAAAQA~_P3JfUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
told me yesterday. “Carlson reassured viewers that their discomfort was
reasonable — that they didn’t have to feel bad about their fears and worries.”

Carlson did so by embracing Trumpism but not Trump himself. The approach was
partly personal. In private texts, Carlson said of Trump, “I hate him
passionately.” It also helped Carlson differentiate himself from other Fox News
hosts, Nicholas said. Because they aligned themselves closely with Trump, the
hosts Sean Hannity and Laura Ingraham would often have to come to his defense
when Trump said something outrageous. Carlson tried to avoid those pitfalls by
focusing on the underlying message instead of Trump as the public face of it.

Fox’s predominantly white audience embraced Carlson’s approach, and he drew more
than three million viewers a night, regularly making his show No. 1 or No. 2 at
the network. And although accusations of bigotry and falsehoods prompted
sponsors to flee Fox, Carlson’s show increased its ad revenue because its
audience was so large.

Carlson has not said what he’ll do next. But without that big audience, he
probably won’t be as influential.


UNCERTAIN FUTURE

Fox News said it would rotate hosts in its 8 p.m. slot until it could find a
permanent replacement. At first glance, this seems bad for the network: Not only
did it lose one of its biggest stars, but it has no replacement lined up. And
the announcement comes at a time when Fox has already faced months of bad
publicity, and it just agreed to a $787.5 million settlement over Dominion’s
lawsuit.

But Fox has overcome similar challenges with its hosts before. Carlson himself
replaced Bill O’Reilly, who was once the network’s most popular host, and not
only maintained O’Reilly’s ratings but at times surpassed them. That experience
may have led Fox to believe that the network carries more sway over its viewers
than individual hosts do.

The former Fox executive Roger Ailes used to occasionally bench his prime time
stars for a night to show them that the ratings stayed high when they were gone
— demonstrating that it was Fox that made them big, Nicholas noted. “I suspect
the audience loyalty to Fox is probably greater than the audience loyalty to any
particular Fox star,” he added.


FOR MORE

 * A lack of premium advertisers in recent years had done little to hurt
   Carlson’s standing
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/SywL1j0cIQbyo6CNqS5R5Q~~/AAAAAQA~_P3JfUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
   at Fox News.
 * Trump and Carlson patched up
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/u9pRIJievpb1Sn8q72KXXg~~/AAAAAQA~_P3JfUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
   their differences recently.
 * CNN fired the host Don Lemon
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/IaAiGu6XyW66O6GSuklEUw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjUTP0TaaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNC9idXNpbmVzcy9tZWRpYS9kb24tbGVtb24tY25uLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTAwMyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTI5MCZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD4TsEdk_z9yX1IZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~],
   who lost executives’ support after an uproar over a sexist comment he made on
   air.
 * The departures of Carlson and Lemon mark the end of an era in media
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/xHF4BP4DTrrFxPZVDQo8lQ~~/AAAAAQA~-E7BHZP8_cl9SGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~],
   The Times’s Jim Rutenberg writes.
 * Jeff Shell, the chief executive of NBCUniversal, was fired after a news
   anchor
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/lcgDQpX-2tA9iNBxKgzm2w~~/AAAAAQA~-E7BHZP8_cl9SGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   lodged a sexual harassment complaint against him.
 * Carlson’s departure is part of a Fox tradition in which abuse is tolerated
   until it’s inconvenient, Michelle Goldberg writes
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/1AVUIe2IP1ryJtDRzvUcjA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjUTP0TmaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNC9vcGluaW9uL3R1Y2tlci1jYXJsc29uLWZveC1uZXdzLWRvbWluaW9uLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTAwMyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTI5MCZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD4TsEdk_z9yX1IZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
   in Times Opinion.
 * “Never put anything in an email”: Carlson’s dismissal represents a cautionary
   tale that Rupert Murdoch learned years ago, Bret Stephens writes
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/f4JGthK7xCcopGISs-PB8g~~/AAAAAQA~_P3JfUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
   in Times Opinion.
 * Late night hosts joked about Carlson’s departure
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ZKy3Z3f0wWQr1RunmABqMw~~/AAAAAQA~-E7BHZP8_cl9SGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].

Continue reading the main story


A MESSAGE FROM GE AEROSPACE

Invention is in the air

In 2022 alone, nearly 3 billion people flew with our technology under wing. But
the boundaries of more sustainable air travel exist to be pushed, and we’ll
continue doing so with the mission to invent the future of flight, lift people
up, and bring them home safely.

Learn More

GE Aerospace Logo
[https://static01.nytimes.com/ads/email_logo/Morning_briefing/us/GE_Logo_150X150.png]
[ge.com]


THE LATEST NEWS

Politics

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/25/multimedia/25-THE-MORNING-NL-biden-pgqk/25-THE-MORNING-NL-biden-pgqk-jumbo.jpg]President
Biden.Doug Mills/The New York Times

 * Biden announced his re-election bid
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/FkYyRpLaZI_svvlA6T7eEA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjUTP0TmaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNS91cy9wb2xpdGljcy9iaWRlbi1ydW5uaW5nLTIwMjQtcHJlc2lkZW50Lmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTAwMyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTI5MCZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD4TsEdk_z9yX1IZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~],
   setting up the possibility of a rematch with Donald Trump. Follow our updates
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/mRk75ZgG7X4R0qR7-ce4Jw~~/AAAAAQA~_P3JfUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].
 * A jury will start hearing E. Jean Carroll’s allegation today that Trump raped
   her in a department store
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/mmMSlpzOwdVk20IsOZLmwA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjUTP0TmaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNS9ueXJlZ2lvbi90cnVtcC1yYXBlLXRyaWFsLWUtamVhbi1jYXJyb2xsLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTAwMyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTI5MCZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD4TsEdk_z9yX1IZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
   dressing room more than two decades ago.

 * The North Dakota governor signed a bill banning abortion
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/Sv4299GE37RA2DYjbBkUfA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjUTP0TaaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNC91cy9hYm9ydGlvbi1iYW4tbm9ydGgtZGFrb3RhLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTAwMyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTI5MCZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD4TsEdk_z9yX1IZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
   after six weeks of pregnancy, even in cases of rape or incest.
 * The College Board will change its A.P. African American Studies course
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/QpBd9XqkyqgmhvAjshgTyQ~~/AAAAAQA~-E7BHZP8_cl9SGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   after scholars accused it of bending to political pressure and omitting key
   concepts.

International

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/24/multimedia/25themorning-ukraine/25themorning-ukraine-jumbo-v2.jpg]Ukrainian
recruits in the Kyiv region.Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

Invention is in the air

In 2022 alone, nearly 3 billion people flew with our technology under wing. But
the boundaries of more sustainable air travel exist to be pushed, and we’ll
continue doing so with the mission to invent the future of flight, lift people
up, and bring them home safely.
