A POP SONG ON TRIAL

Did Ed Sheeran copy his Grammy-winning ballad “Thinking Out Loud” from Marvin
Gaye’s soul classic “Let’s Get It On”? The question is at the center of a
copyright trial
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/n49xdbpiaXpwEUFaamnk0w~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjUTP0TvaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNC9hcnRzL211c2ljL2VkLXNoZWVyYW4tbWFydmluLWdheWUtY29weXJpZ2h0LXRyaWFsLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTAwMyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTI5MCZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD4TsEdk_z9yX1IZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
that began yesterday in federal court in Manhattan.

Because of a quirk of music copyrights, the case rests primarily on the songs’
chord progressions, which are nearly identical, as this video comparison shows
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/uCjv1U0iszs57l7GhC3-Kg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjUTP0SyaHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS96MVl4RmpRWGJYZz9jYW1wYWlnbl9pZD05JmVtYz1lZGl0X25uXzIwMjMwNDI1Jmluc3RhbmNlX2lkPTkxMDAzJm5sPXRoZS1tb3JuaW5nJnJlZ2lfaWQ9MTk4NTAyODY1JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMjkwJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1mYTYwY2U2NjQ3NzlmZmM0MjI5NTg4MTA1YmYyMjhlN1cDbnl0QgpkPhOwR2T_P3JfUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].
But Sheeran’s lawyers have argued that the chords are common in pop music —
including in songs by artists who used them before Gaye and Ed Townsend, who
collaborated with him on “Let’s Get It On,” did.

-1591831093.subject: [Legal Notice] Changes to Google Maps Platform Data Privacy Terms for US and UK users
-1591831093.text:
Hello Google Maps Customer,

We’re writing to let you know we updated our Controller-Controller Data Protection Terms for Google Maps Platform on January 23, 2023.

What do you need to know?

The updates to our Protection Terms are the result of the adoption by the UK of the International Data Transfer Agreement (IDTA) Addendum[1] and changes to several US state’s privacy laws. You can review the specific updates to each country below:

   - For the US:
     - We added a US State Privacy Laws Addendum[2] to the Controller-Controller Data Protection Terms[3] to support data protection laws in California, Colorado, Connecticut, Utah, and Virginia.
     - The US State Privacy Laws Addendum has replaced the previous CCPA Addendum (which only applied to California) as of January 1, 2023.
   - For the UK:
     - From March 2022, the UK International Data Transfer Agreement (IDTA) Addendum allows the EU Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs) to be used for transfers of personal data under the UK GDPR.
     - We removed the previously required UK specific Standard Contractual Clauses as they are no longer necessary.
     - You can review Google Maps Platform’s SCCs[4].

These updates won’t affect your use of other Google products or services as they will only apply to Google Maps Platform.

What do you need to do?

No action is required on your part.

We’re here to help

If you have any questions or concerns about this update, please contact Google Maps Platform Support[5].

Thanks for choosing Google Maps Platform.

–The Google Maps Platform Team

[1] https://ico.org.uk/for-organisations/guide-to-data-protection/guide-to-the-general-data-protection-regulation-gdpr/international-data-transfer-agreement-and-guidance/
[2] https://business.safety.google/controllerterms/us-state-laws/
[3] https://business.safety.google/controllerterms/
[4] https://business.safety.google/gdprcontrollerterms/sccs/eu-c2c/
[5] https://support.google.com/cloud/contact/maps_api_privacy

© 2023 Google LLC 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, Mountain View, CA 94043

You have received this mandatory service announcement to update you about important changes to Google Maps Platform or your account.

-33139116.subject: It all comes down to The Game!
-33139116.text:
Crimson hosts #16 Yale in must win game on Saturday!


 (https://t.e2ma.net/click/w2zrbh/k1yo3eh/o008sq)


 (https://t.e2ma.net/click/w2zrbh/k1yo3eh/4s18sq)


Harvard vs. #16 Yale

Saturday, April 29 | Noon | Jordan Field



It all comes down to The Game! Be there live as your Harvard Crimson Men's Lacrosse team hosts #16 Yale this Saturday for its final regular season game at Jordan Field.

It is a win or go home game for both teams, as the winner of the contest will decide the fourth and final team in the 2023 Ivy League Tournament field!


Get Tickets (https://t.e2ma.net/click/w2zrbh/k1yo3eh/kl28sq)




IVY STANDINGS


 (https://t.e2ma.net/click/w2zrbh/k1yo3eh/0d38sq)


1\. Cornell* (10-2, 4-1)

2\. Princeton* (6-5, 4-1)

3\. Penn* (6-5, 4-2)

4\. Yale* (7-4, 2-3)

5\. Harvard (5-6, 2-3)

6\. Dartmouth (6-5, 1-4)

7\. Brown (5-7, 1-4)

*Top four teams advance to the Ivy League Tournament.

QUESTIONS?

If you have any questions, please contact the Harvard Athletics Ticket Office at HarvTix@fas.harvard.edu (mailto:HarvTix@fas.harvard.edu?subject=) or tel:617-495-2211 (tel:617-495-2211).


 (https://t.e2ma.net/click/w2zrbh/k1yo3eh/g638sq)


 (https://t.e2ma.net/click/w2zrbh/k1yo3eh/wy48sq)

-1036827192.subject: [Bacch-talk]  Fwd: [HMChat] FREE BOBA THIS TOMORROW 4/25 @ 7PM HARVARD HALL 202 | DISSECTING AAPI: COMMUNITY, IDENTITY, & POLITICS
-1036827192.text:
Hello everyone,

To kick off Asian American Pacific Islander Heritage Month in May, AAA will
be hosting a panel discussion and Q&A with members of the Harvard community
in Harvard Hall room 202 this Tuesday! Come join us for free boba and an
incredible conversation on what it means to be AAPI and the incredible work
some of our speakers have done on campus and beyond!

In solidarity,
Kawsar Yasin & Kashish Bastola
Education/Political Co-Chairs
Asian American Association

[image: Dissecting AAPI (1).png]

-1996611608.subject: [Bacch-talk]  Public Service Weekly: ARTS FIRST; job search for seniors; +more
-1996611608.text:
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=0375a2138f&e=bfd81953e7>

*Service StorySlam*

Sunday, April 30, 2023
Lowell Lecture Hall
17 Kirkland St.
12:00pm - 1:00pm

Come hear undergraduates share how different service experiences
challenged, changed, and shifted them!  This will be a live storytelling
event. Our goal is to bring the Harvard community together to listen and
learn from student service experiences that center the successes and
failures that inevitably occur in community engagement.

This conversation will feature:

   - Heba Mohamed, '23: The Power of Showing Up
   - Veronica Ruiz '26: Community, Community, Community
   - Tarina Ahuja, '24: Resiliency & Trolls
   - Jeremy Orenstein '24: Pitfalls of Planning a Revolution

*Click here to register!*
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=268e109f9e&e=bfd81953e7>
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=3b5733de7a&e=bfd81953e7>

Volunteer at Harvard’s largest arts festival!

Be a part of ARTS FIRST, on Saturday, April 29, 2023! Do you want
experience working at Harvard’s longest-running arts festival? We are
seeking volunteers to help set up, clean up, greet audience members, hand
out ARTS FIRST programs, and keep performance venues running smoothly.
All volunteers will get a free ARTS FIRST t-shirt!

*Please fill out this form to volunteer!
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=890900c5dd&e=bfd81953e7>*




<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=7e2bea65fe&e=bfd81953e7>
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=cf1fd923a0&e=bfd81953e7>
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=59387023be&e=bfd81953e7>

*Slave Legacy History Coalition Virtual Event*
Apr 26, 10:30 AM – 12:00 PM

The Slave Legacy History Coalition is a consortium of individuals,
organizations, and institutions engaged in the preservation of the history
of enslaved people in the Cambridge, Boston communities and beyond. The
Slave Legacy History Coalition was established in the fall of 2021 by the
Lloyd Family descendants of Tony, Cuba, and Darby, whose enslavers Henry
Vassall and Penelope Royall endowed the first law professorships at Harvard
University, which eventually became Harvard Law School. Since its
establishment in the fall of 2021, the Slave Legacy History Coalition has
developed educational programming and monthly virtual gatherings to bring
together local organizations engaged in the work of documenting the
histories tied to slavery and the accomplishments of slave descendants. The
purpose of the Slave Legacy History Coalition is to provide easier access
to information and resources on the legacy of slavery before and after
emancipation for the families of slave descendants and the general public.

*Featuring Jonathan Knight – Producer/Director*

A filmmaker and Visual Effects supervisor. With 19 years experience in
Visual Effects. Invented Before You Were Born is Jonathan’s first project
as a director. Growing up in Cambridge, MA, he now lives inthe San
Francisco Bay Area.

Jonathan is an active member of SURJ (Showing Up for Racial Justice) in
Marin County. He is also an active supporter of the SEEK Museum in
Russellville, KY. He is not a professional historian, but became interested
in his own family history and connection to slavery in response to the
white supremacist uprisings in 2017. Through engaging with this history and
the people who are its legacy, Jonathan has found connection, purpose, and
new family.

*Click here to RSVP!
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=fab4bd7336&e=bfd81953e7>*

Please look at your bookshelves: Which books will you probably never read
again? Your desert island scenario may never come to pass, so why not send
them where they're needed?

@harvard.library
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=72523cd1dd&e=bfd81953e7>
is
participating in the Prison Book Program Paperback Book Drive, through
which these books go to people incarcerated across the country.

Drop-off dates: April 3–28, 2023

*Please donate: *

   - Gently used (or almost new) paperback books
   - Fiction & nonfiction books on all topics
   - No hardcovers or spiral bound


*Drop-off locations:*

   - Schlesinger Library lobby, Harvard Radcliffe Institute
   - Lamont Library lobby, Harvard Yard

For anyone in NYC this weekend, check out a panel at the UN Forum on
Indigenous Issues that some of our very own students will be presenting on
Friday, April 28th from 10:30-11:30 at the KJCC Auditorium!
(located at 53 Washington Square South, New York City)
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=325a00d8d5&e=bfd81953e7>
*The Harvard Center for International Development's Global Empowerment
Meeting*, in partnership with the *Harvard Climate Coalition*, is hosting a
climate art competition for students to submit their work in alignment with
the theme of the conference, *GEM23: “GEM23: "Growing in a Green World
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=23cc1b25c7&e=bfd81953e7>."*


*Submissions are open to artistic interpretation, and all forms of media
are encouraged. Submission types may include but are not limited to
drawing, painting, photography, mixed media, digital art, video, dance,
fiber arts, pottery, and poetry. *

*Five winners will receive the prize of a $100 Visa Gift Card*.
Additionally, all artists will have the opportunity to showcase their work
and themselves as artists in relation to climate and environment during a
90-minute session at the meeting to attendees. (Some artwork may only be
able to be presented in digital format.)

*Submissions are due via this Final Submission
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=ac04112df9&e=bfd81953e7>**
form
by 11:59 pm on Monday, May 1st.* Artists planning on submitting are highly
encouraged to fill out the preliminary interest
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=80342c0985&e=bfd81953e7>
form
as soon as possible.
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=f261081aac&e=bfd81953e7>


Summer 2023 Radcliffe Engaged Student Grant Program

The Radcliffe Engaged Student Grant Program
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=67732d6ba8&e=bfd81953e7>
provides $1,500
stipends (per project) to support the research, creative, and service work
of Harvard undergraduate and graduate students on topics related to
the Radcliffe Engaged focus areas: 1.) Law, Education, and Justice, and 2.)
Climate Change and Climate* Justice. *The summer grant period runs from
June - August 2023.

All applications must be received by 11:59 PM EDT on Monday, May 1, 2023. Click
here to apply
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=8d202f4a2a&e=bfd81953e7>
.

If you have any questions, please reach out to Amanda Lubniewski:
amanda_lubniewski@radcliffe.harvard.edu
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=29998b5241&e=bfd81953e7>
[image: Twitter]
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=381f27eeed&e=bfd81953e7>
[image: Facebook]
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=45cb5f84e4&e=bfd81953e7>
[image: Website]
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=51bff0ab0c&e=bfd81953e7>
Public Service Weekly is a publication from the Center for Public Service
and Engaged Scholarship
<https://harvard.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=bd3499f4b260aab50b71b5034&id=cb1304419a&e=bfd81953e7>.
All questions should be directed to publicservice@fas.harvard.edu.

Cc: Boehler, Christine <christine_boehler@harvard.edu<mailto:christine_boehler@harvard.edu>>, Nozzolillo, Alixandra A <alixandra_nozzolillo@harvard.edu<mailto:alixandra_nozzolillo@harvard.edu>>, Luster, Charnele S <charnele_luster@fas.harvard.edu<mailto:charnele_luster@fas.harvard.edu>>
Subject: Lowell House Merchandise
Hello everyone-
Is there something else needed from Lowell? I thought we had approval for this latest order. This kind of lag time concerns me. We really need this order in the works right away or students won't be able to get their merchandise. Can someone from the College please help us expedite through Trademark?

I also left Trademark a voice mail message this morning.

Please advise, and thank you!

Beth

Elizabeth Terry, Administrator ~  ~  ~   Lowell House, 10 Holyoke Place, Cambridge MA 02138 ~  ~  ~  eterry@fas.harvard.edu<mailto:eterry@fas.harvard.edu>

________________________________
From: Andy Zhuo <azhuo@college.harvard.edu<mailto:azhuo@college.harvard.edu>>
Sent: Friday, April 21, 2023 4:53 PM
To: Brandt, Lauren Elizabeth <lbrandt@fas.harvard.edu<mailto:lbrandt@fas.harvard.edu>>
Cc: Harvard Trademark Swag <trademark_swag@harvard.edu<mailto:trademark_swag@harvard.edu>>; Boehler, Christine <christine_boehler@harvard.edu<mailto:christine_boehler@harvard.edu>>; Nozzolillo, Alixandra A <alixandra_nozzolillo@harvard.edu<mailto:alixandra_nozzolillo@harvard.edu>>; Luster, Charnele S <charnele_luster@fas.harvard.edu<mailto:charnele_luster@fas.harvard.edu>>; Terry, Elizabeth <eterry@fas.harvard.edu<mailto:eterry@fas.harvard.edu>>
Subject: Re: Lowell House Merch Approval

Hi everyone,

Happy Friday! I placed 5 orders with CustomInk (one for each of the item types) just over a week ago, and it seems like they are all still in the process of being reviewed for trademark approval. I understand that there is typically a 7-10 day turnaround for this. I just want to put it on your radar in case there are any potential delays in communications between the Trademark Office and CustomInk.

I appreciate all of your help in streamlining this process, especially given how close we are to the semester. Thanks again, and have a great weekend!

Best,
Andy

On Thu, Apr 13, 2023 at 7:00 PM Andy Zhuo <azhuo@college.harvard.edu<mailto:azhuo@college.harvard.edu>> wrote:
Hi Lauren,

Thank you so much for the clarification! I will definitely keep that in mind for the future. I did submit that online form yesterday, so please let me know if there are any issues.

All the best,
Andy

Hi Andy,



Thank you for the cc. I appreciate all of the work you’ve done on this!

Normally, these designs are sent to the DSO (Charnele and me) in advance, so we can review beforehand. You can also find the process to follow and the appropriate form here:

https://trademark.harvard.edu/guidelines-ordering-internal-insignia-items-swag



Just to confirm – have you completed the online form mentioned at that link?



Cc’ing Beth so she is aware as well.



Sincerely,



Lauren

I hope you are all doing well! I am Andy, one of the merch co-chairs for Lowell House. -414159694.subject: [Bacch-talk]  Fwd: Seeking Climate Education Interviews for Radcliffe Research Partnerships Project
-414159694.text:
Forwarding for a friend! Please sign up for an interview if you can :)

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Henry Wu <hhwu@college.harvard.edu>
Date: Wed, Apr 26, 2023 at 3:08 PM
Subject: Seeking Climate Education Interviews for Radcliffe Research
Partnerships Project
To:


Hi everyone!

I am seeking undergraduate students to interview for my Radcliffe Research
Partnerships project on climate education with Dr. Hong Yang
<https://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/people/hong-yang>. We are studying
barriers to climate education in colleges and universities and hoping to
understand student and faculty views on the topic. I am offering 30-minute
interview slots next week (May 1-6), which you can sign up for here
<https://calendar.app.google/BkAavwUdP3Jj74di8>. Regardless of whether or
not you study something related to the environment or have taken a
climate-related course, I would greatly appreciate hearing your thoughts!
Please send this along to anyone who you think might be interested!

Thanks,
Henry

-953899743.subject: You're Invited! 📩
-953899743.text:
View this email in your browser (https://mailchi.mp/06fa09d0291d/tvyvzjfc9l-3178037?e=3cca8ea97d)
https://dso.college.harvard.edu
You're Invited!
This is our last edition of You're Invited for the semester!
Good luck with finals & enjoy your summer ☀️
Want your event featured in You're Invited? Submit events with our newsletter event submission form (https://form.jotform.com/92485668784175) ! The deadline for submissions is Tuesdays at 5pm EST. You MUST submit a flyer with your submission form. This newsletter goes out every Wednesday.

Gallery Talk: Activation of Moholy-Nagy’s Light Prop for an Electric Stage (https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/gallery-talk-activation-of-moholy-nagy-s-light-prop-for-an-electric-stage-27?utm_source=museummarketing&utm_medium=listing&utm_campaign=April+light+prop&utm_id=April+Talk%3A+Activation+of+Moholy-Nagy’s+L)
April 27th
12:30PM EST
Join staff as they discuss and activate this experimental device from 1930 by László Moholy-Nagy, a Bauhaus pioneer.

Gender Focus Group (https://www.instagram.com/p/CrJqSk-p-Ji/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link)
What would it look like to build healthy relationships that set a stronger foundation to address patterns of gender and power-based violence? The Harvard College Women's Center and SHARE (Sexual Harassment/Assault Resources and Education) are hoping to host a series of gender-based affinity spaces for the university community in 2023. Come join us and help shape the conversations by attending these focus groups or reaching out via email to hcwc@fas.harvard.edu (mailto:hcwc@fas.harvard.edu) or oge_share@harvard.edu (mailto:oge_share@harvard.edu) .
Harvard Art Museums at Night (https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/harvard-art-museums-at-night-12?utm_source=museummarketing&utm_medium=listing&utm_campaign=April+At+Night&utm_id=April+Harvard+Art+Museums+at+Night)
April 27th
5:00PM EST
Join us for an evening of art, fun, food, and more!
This event is free and open to everyone.

Tireless Sacred Work: Performance and Conversation with Ezra Furman (https://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/event/2023-tireless-sacred-work-performance)
April 27th
7:00PM EST
Singer, songwriter, musician, and critic Ezra Furman will perform and open Harvard Radcliffe Institute's “Minding the Gap: Gender and the Mental Health Crisis” conference. Through music and conversation, she will explore themes of identity and anxiety, angst and fearlessness.

In The Shadow of Giants (https://cglink.me/2rf/r376663)
April 27th
6:00PM EST
We’re not just making history, we’re keeping it alive.
This Thursday at the Smith Campus Center, Black Arts Collective presents In the Shadows of Giants.  Featuring student performances, a panel on the ethics of cultural preservation, and a Vanguard-award ceremony, this event is free and open to the public. For more information, go to the blackartcollective_ (https://www.instagram.com/blackartscollective_/) instagram page.

Post Mortem: the 28th Harvard First-Year Musical (https://soco.college.harvard.edu/257952/rsvp_boot?id=376665)
April 27th
7:30PM EST
The Office for the Arts at Harvard and the Harvard-Radcliffe Dramatic Club are proud to present Post Mortem (https://sites.google.com/view/firstyearmusical) , the 28th Harvard First-Year Musical. Entirely written, directed, acted, and produced by First-Year students, coming to the Agassiz House Theatre in late April. Visit the musical website to learn more!
TDM Spring 2023 Production: The Singularity Play (https://tdm.fas.harvard.edu/current-productions#singularity)
At Google, an artificial intelligence named Denise has written a play and the company has hired a downtown troupe of theatre performers to help her develop it, but rehearsals start to eat away at the edges of reality, and soon we're unsure if we're watching a play or watching reality, watching humans perform characters or watching characters perform being human.
HUECU Book Drive (https://www.abedforeverychild.org/ccua)
Help young bookworms thrive. The Massachusetts Credit Unions are hosting a “Children’s Book Drive" in April. Donate new or gently used books by April 28th at one of HUECU's branches: Harvard Square (HSQ), Mass General (MGH), or Longwood Medical Area (LMA).

Minding the Gap: Gender and the Mental Health Crisis (https://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/event/2023-minding-the-gap-conference)
April 28th
9:00AM EST
Harvard Radcliffe Institute’s 2023 gender conference will explore the relationship between gender and mental health, with a focus on youth, underserved communities, and the impact of social justice issues.

Harvard Baseball vs Columbia | Featured Game (https://gocrimson.com/sports/baseball)
April 28th
11:30AM EST
Come join Harvard Baseball at O’Donnell Field as they host Columbia in their featured game. Undergraduate students in attendance will receive a FREE ROPE HAT (while supplies last)!
Harvard Men's Lightweight Rowing | Goldthwait & Vogel Cups | Featured Race (https://gocrimson.com/sports/mens-lightweight-rowing)
Come join Harvard Men’s Lightweight Rowing this Saturday for their featured race, as they host Yale and Princeton in the Goldthwait & Vogel Cups. Undergraduate students in attendance will receive a FREE bucket hat (while supplies last)!
ARTS FIRST - Free Admission Day (https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/free-admission-day-for-arts-first-6?utm_source=museummarketing&utm_medium=listing&utm_campaign=Arts+First&utm_id=Free+Admission+Day+for+ARTS+FIRST)
April 29th
In celebration of the ARTS FIRST Festival, The Harvard Art Museum is offering a free day of admission this Saturday! See the ARTS FIRST page (https://ofa.fas.harvard.edu/arts) for more information.
Harvard Men's Lacrosse vs #16 Yale | House Sticker Giveaway Contest (https://gocrimson.com/sports/mens-lacrosse)
April 29th
12:00PM EST
Let's Go Crimson!
This Saturday, Harvard Men's Lacrosse hosts Yale in a crucial Ivy matchup. Each student in attendance will receive a laptop sticker of their House crest. The House with the largest turnout will get FREE pizza during finals week!
Bacchanalia (https://cglink.me/2rf/r376471)
$15 formal!
This Saturday at Lowell House, enjoy music, food, and drinks! Open to ALL! Purchase tickets at the Harvard College Student Events Funds (https://sef.cloud.huit.harvard.edu/) website or here (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfF_h9YtwTpbSxQlugno6mqpJ_JT1vDYfpCBMUWNE0RtFaBcg/viewform) .
HRO and Harvard Choruses Present Verdi's Requiem (https://boxoffice.harvard.edu/Online/default.asp?BOparam::WScontent::loadArticle::permalink=harvard-radcliffe-orchestra&BOparam::WScontent::loadArticle::context_id=)
Join the Harvard-Radcliffe Orchestra and the Harvard Choruses (Harvard Glee Club, Radcliffe Choral Society, Harvard-Radcliffe Collegium Musicum) for a monumental performance of Verdi’s Requiem this Sunday in Sanders Theater! Under the baton of HRO Music Director Federico Cortese, 250 Harvard students will perform alongside world-renowned soloists Raquel Gonzalez (Soprano), Renee Tatum (Mezzo-Soprano), Cooper Nolan (Tenor), and Weston Hurt (Bass). Tickets available at the Harvard Box Office (https://boxoffice.harvard.edu/Online/default.asp) .
Gallery Talk: Paintings in Residence—Works from the Terra Foundation for American Art (https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/gallery-talk-paintings-in-residence-works-from-the-terra-foundation-for-american-art-3?utm_source=museummarketing&utm_medium=listing&utm_campaign=Terra+Foundation+May+3&utm_id=Gallery+Talk%3A+Paintings+in+Reside)
May 3rd
12:30PM EST
Join Kimia Shahi as she discusses an iconic 19th-century painting, on loan from the Terra Foundation for American Art.

President's Innovation Challenge (https://www.eventbrite.com/e/2023-harvard-presidents-innovation-challenge-awards-ceremony-registration-566582111347)
Harvard's annual celebration of innovation, community, and entrepreneurship. We’ll hear live pitches from 25 finalist teams and reveal which of the freshest and most forward-thinking ventures will receive a share of $515,000 in funding, courtesy of the Bertarelli Foundation. Finalists have been selected from a diverse group of 158 PIC semi-finalist teams with representation from each of Harvard’s 13 schools and over 30 countries around the world.

Gallery Talk—A World Within Reach: Greek and Roman Art from the Loeb Collection (https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/gallery-talk-em-a-world-within-reach-greek-and-roman-art-from-the-loeb-collection-em-4?utm_source=museummarketing&utm_medium=listing&utm_campaign=May_loeb&utm_id=Gallery+Talk%E2%80%94A+World+Within+Reach%3A+Gree)
May 4th
12:30PM EST
Amy Brauer and Caitlin Clerkin will explore what can be revealed by looking closely at small-scale ancient Greek and Roman art.

Harvard & the Legacy of Slavery: Our Path Forward (https://www.harvard.edu/vice-provost-for-special-projects/1268-2/)
Join an engaging conversation with Roeshana Moore-Evans, Executive Director of the Harvard & the Legacy of Slavery Initiative, and Sara Bleich, Vice Provost for Special Projects. Light refreshments will be served.

Make sure to follow us on social media below!
https://dso.college.harvard.edu/student-engagement
https://www.instagram.com/harvardstudentengagement/
https://www.facebook.com/HarvardStudentEngagement

-1593805638.text:
Happy end of classes STAHRlings!

Despite the forecast calling for scattered clouds in the evening and the
cumulus currently lurking outside, *THE STAHR OPEN HOUSE WILL BE HAPPENING
TONIGHT AT 7:30PM!!* We present figure 1 to demonstrate the thought process:
[image: 7jkwd0.jpg]

Sunset will be happening at 7:38pm *SHARP* so get there right at 7:30 to
witness the Sun setting on the semester (well, the non-finals part of it
anyway). We're also planning to look at the Moon!

TLDR: come to the Observatory and vibe with us while the friendly
neighborhood uncontrolled thermonuclear reaction disappears behind the
curvature of the Earth.

Cheers,
STAHR Board


PS: To those who, like your hapless Secretary, have an evening exam on the
last day of classes: I am so so sorry! Please drop by afterwards if you're
able, but we will be ending at 9pm.

-2097615413.subject: [Bacch-talk]  WATCH THE SINGULARITY PLAY THIS WEEKEND!!!
-2097615413.text:
RESERVE YOUR FREE TICKETS NOW!
<https://us14.mailchimp.com/mctx/clicks?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fforms%2Fd%2Fe%2F1FAIpQLScrWZu35UXnQMbBLIFClaiyl9QwWrdRnPv8fU0D0bdytXCGqQ%2Fviewform&xid=c54dfca24b&uid=190657762&iid=f5fce17982&pool=cts&v=2&c=1682564834&h=5bc4cec5b101517f828d95a43a29000dc3b5c896a7b3128d35a4f14c75ca6e97>

At Google, an artificial intelligence named Denise has written a play and
the company has hired a downtown troupe of theatre performers to help her
develop it, but rehearsals start to eat away at the edges of reality, and
soon we're unsure if we're watching a play or watching reality, watching
humans perform characters or watching characters perform being human.





*Thursday April 27th @ 7pmFriday April 28th @ 7pmSaturday April 29th @
2pmSaturday April 29th @ 7pmSunday April 30th @ 2pm*

The performance will be held at Farkas Hall
(12 Holyoke St, Cambridge, MA 02138)

-1289053263.subject: [Outing Club] Sunrise Hike to Middlesex Fells!
-1289053263.text:
Do you want to fight the finals stress before it sets in?

Do you want to brag to all your friends that you have been up since before
the sun rose (even though it wasn’t to study?

Do you need to spend some time outdoors, pretending it's as warm as it was
last week?

If so, join Samantha Galvin, Jordan Robbins, and Jonathan Zhang this Friday
on a sunrise hike at the Middlesex Fells Reservation!

WHEN: Saturday, April 29, meet in the MAC parking lot at 5:00 A.M., we will
most likely be back before 8:30 AM!

WHAT: A chill sunrise hike around the Middlesex Fells....you do not need
any past hiking experience for this trip

WHO: YOU.

IF YOU ARE ACCEPTED: there is a mandatory pre-trip meeting this Friday @ 12
pm in the rabbit hole (lev basement!)

COSTS:

Somewhere in the ballpark of $15 a person!

HOC Dues: $20 for 6 months, entitling you to unlimited trips and gear
rentals

Financial Aid: No questions asked. Financial cost should not be a factor
for your decision to hike with us!

SIGN UP HERE:  here
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeadwB2vcZHoTwjGLoQyRZaE3dgmUi9APdQEEbuWqBjMFJNjg/viewform?usp=sf_link>

HOC LOVE 🌲🍁,

Samantha Galvin

Harvard College

Class of 2024

_______________________________________________
The Harvard Outing Club, Inc.

To learn more about the club, upcoming trips, and how to get more involved, check out our website at http://harvardoutingclub.org or like us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/HarvardOC.

To unsubscribe send an email to outing-list-leave@lists.fas.harvard.edu
https://web.lists.fas.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/outing-list

-482733582.subject: [Outing Club] Escape the Library!! Come to Middlesex Fells this Saturday !!
-482733582.text:
It’s warm! The sun is out! In 10 years, you won’t remember the grade on
your final but you WILL remember this Cambridge adventure!!

Come for a morning hike with Grace “the sunlight streaming into Widener is
pulling me outside” Bolner and Eddie “I can’t sit in Lamont and look at
people sitting outside for literally another second” Dai at Middlesex
Fells!!!

Look at this Boston skyline!! Where else could you get this view??!!

[image: image.png][image: image.png]

When: Saturday, April 29th. We’ll meet at 8:30 am, aiming to be back by
noon!

What: A lively, brisk 2.8-mile hike with a 300 ft elevation gain. Rated
“Maple” by HOC’s trip classification
<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1laoQfLBWqYE2Q31rvjkLDpYWxwURWvWjy3aV87iykro/edit>
!

Who: You. Me. The birds. The rocks. The trees.

SIGN UP HERE!!
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfD8G77t7CPn3tBDceulz1VbPEBQu-nk9zhG69RZ8TJkMJSLQ/viewform>
by
Thursday, April 27th at 7:00 pm!!

If we have a higher number of signups than spots, we will run a lottery. If
accepted, we will have a mandatory pre-trip meeting on Zoom on Friday at
6pm!!

Costs for this trip are expected to be around $12 for transportation plus
the HOC membership fee of $20, if you have yet to pay. But :):) HOC offers
no-questions-asked financial aid so cost should never be a barrier to get
outside and join us for an adventure !!!

LIVE LOVE TREES !!!

LET’S GO FOR A HIKE !!!

Gracie B and Eddie D

_______________________________________________
The Harvard Outing Club, Inc.

To learn more about the club, upcoming trips, and how to get more involved, check out our website at http://harvardoutingclub.org or like us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/HarvardOC.

To unsubscribe send an email to outing-list-leave@lists.fas.harvard.edu
https://web.lists.fas.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/outing-list

-87763890.subject: [Outing Club] Stroll Through Alewife Brook on Friday!!!
-87763890.text:
Are you getting busy as we slip into reading period? Do you hate studying
and love nature? Do you want to leave everything behind and spend a few
hours here?


[image: image.png]



Join Grace "I love the T" Benkelman and James “I have never ridden to
Alewife” Glaser on a beautiful walk around *Alewife Brook Reservation*.


What: Probably like 3 miles. Pretty flat. A sweet nature walk far enough
from campus to be away but close enough to not worry about your work. This
is maple on the HOC difficulty scale
<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1laoQfLBWqYE2Q31rvjkLDpYWxwURWvWjy3aV87iykro/edit>.
Weather will be the same as it is here.


When: Leave on THIS FRIDAY (April 28th)  at 7:00 am from the Harvard T
Station and be back by noon.

There will be a pre-trip meeting over Zoom to go over logistics which we
will schedule soon.


How:

   -

   Fill out this form <https://forms.gle/jao8RmmkWB7E8b1b7> by 2pm on
   Wednesday, April 26th
   -

   Depending on the number of signups, we may have to run a lottery for
   slots on the trips. Either way, you can expect to receive an email or text
   regarding your signup status by 3pm on Wednesday
   -

   For those attending the trip, we will have a pre-trip meeting over Zoom
   to go over logistics which we will schedule soon.


Cost:

   -

   HOC membership dues are $20 and last for 6 months, allowing access to
   all HOC trips and gear rentals*
   -

   The expected cost of this trip is around $5, which will cover round-trip
   fare on the Red Line.*
   -

   *As always, HOC offers a no-questions-asked financial aid policy for
   both trip costs and membership.


If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to reach out to
573-825-1247 (James) or 406-291-2762 (Grace)!


HOC love,

Grace and James

_______________________________________________
The Harvard Outing Club, Inc.

To learn more about the club, upcoming trips, and how to get more involved, check out our website at http://harvardoutingclub.org or like us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/HarvardOC.

To unsubscribe send an email to outing-list-leave@lists.fas.harvard.edu
https://web.lists.fas.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/outing-list

-1745413543.subject: Apply by tomorrow night! WorldMUN, an unforgettable experience 🌏
-1745413543.text:
Fully funded spring break trip. No model UN experience necessary.

Travel the world.

Find a family.
No experience needed.

WorldMUN.
Apply by tomorrow night! (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdn8QCYgfsPZh-iox976-R19277YgD4pB_dxuVtkZUJ9lb4Ow/viewform?usp=sf_link)


** Connect.
------------------------------------------------------------

WorldMUN brings together more than 1,000 young leaders from around the globe to engage in fruitful debate on pressing global issues, providing participants with the opportunity to hone their diplomacy skills while building long-lasting connections with peers from diverse backgrounds.


** Travel.
------------------------------------------------------------

WorldMUN 2024, the 32nd iteration of the conference, will take place from March 8 to 18. Past locations have included Paris (2023), Madrid (2019), Panama City (2018), Montreal (2017), Rome (2016), Seoul (2015), Brussels (2014), Melbourne (2013), and Vancouver (2012).

Past WorldMUN conferences have seen: a diplomatic gala in the Louvre (2023), an address from King Felipe VI of Spain (2019), and a speech from Pope Francis (2016).


** The annual application closes soon.
------------------------------------------------------------

Join the tight-knit WorldMUN community today! Visit our website, worldmun.org (http://worldmun.org/) , for more information, and apply via tinyurl.com/wmun24 by 11:59 pm EDT on Friday, April 28.

Please note that we do not have a preference for applicants with model UN experience. In fact, year after year, we find that many of our best chairs join WorldMUN with no prior model UN experience. We will provide all the training necessary to succeed at the conference.

Please email Davin Shi, the Secretary-General, at davinshi@college.harvard.edu (mailto:davinshi@college.harvard.edu?subject=null&body=null) or secretarygeneral@worldmun.org (mailto:secretarygeneral@worldmun.org?subject=null&body=null) if you have any questions about the application process or the WorldMUN experience.
Apply Now (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdn8QCYgfsPZh-iox976-R19277YgD4pB_dxuVtkZUJ9lb4Ow/viewform?usp=sf_link)
Logo

Copyright (C) 2023 Harvard World Model United Nations. All rights reserved.
You are receiving this email because you are a student at Harvard College.
Our mailing address is:
Harvard World Model United Nations
59 Shepard Street
Cambridge, MA 02138
USA
Want to change how you receive these emails?
You can update your preferences (https://worldmun.us17.list-manage.com/profile?u=12fa5cdffc49c7e4bef7f3cdb&id=e870c26ff7&e=dd3377a38c&c=da941db15c) or unsubscribe (https://worldmun.us17.list-manage.com/unsubscribe?u=12fa5cdffc49c7e4bef7f3cdb&id=e870c26ff7&e=dd3377a38c&c=da941db15c)

[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/0fir0-frX0rkLT6qTYdRMQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmLiSaP0SuaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vP2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjgmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTEyNjEmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD0xOTg1MDI4NjUmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0xMzE1NzMmdGU9MSZ1c2VyX2lkPWZhNjBjZTY2NDc3OWZmYzQyMjk1ODgxMDViZjIyOGU3VwNueXRCCmQ-mp9LZP-jbBVSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]

[https://liveintent.newyorktimesinfo.com/imp?s=859181&li=NN&m=fa60ce664779ffc4229588105bf228e7&p=NN_20230428]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/NxhYjxaBaQJTYQfRgcItfA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmLiSaP0SWaHR0cHM6Ly9saXZlaW50ZW50Lm5ld3lvcmt0aW1lc2luZm8uY29tL2NsaWNrP3M9ODU5MTgxJmxpPU5OJm09ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTcmcD1OTl8yMDIzMDQyOCZ0ZT0xJm5sPXRoZS1tb3JuaW5nJmVtYz1lZGl0X25uXzIwMjMwNDI4VwNueXRCCmQ-mp9LZP-jbBVSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~

[https://static.nytimes.com/email-images/N-TheMorning%402x.png]

April 28, 2023

Author Headshot
[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/01/multimedia/David-Leonhardt-Headshot-The-Morning/David-Leonhardt-Headshot-The-Morning-blogSmallThumb-v3.png]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/2EWGkaA8WnZsWuweUnn47g~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmLiSaP0TAaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZGF2aWQtbGVvbmhhcmR0P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjgmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTEyNjEmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD0xOTg1MDI4NjUmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0xMzE1NzMmdGU9MSZ1c2VyX2lkPWZhNjBjZTY2NDc3OWZmYzQyMjk1ODgxMDViZjIyOGU3VwNueXRCCmQ-mp9LZP-jbBVSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~

By David Leonhardt
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/2EWGkaA8WnZsWuweUnn47g~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmLiSaP0TAaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZGF2aWQtbGVvbmhhcmR0P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjgmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTEyNjEmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD0xOTg1MDI4NjUmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0xMzE1NzMmdGU9MSZ1c2VyX2lkPWZhNjBjZTY2NDc3OWZmYzQyMjk1ODgxMDViZjIyOGU3VwNueXRCCmQ-mp9LZP-jbBVSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]

Good morning. Long school closures have put public education — and Randi
Weingarten, the leader of a major teachers’ union — on the defensive.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/30/magazine/28themorning-lede/28themorning-lede-jumbo.jpg]Randi
Weingarten, president of the American Federation of Teachers.Pat Nabong/Chicago
Sun-Times, via Associated Press


THE LONG SHADOW OF SCHOOL CLOSURES

During the early months of the Covid pandemic, Randi Weingarten and the
teachers’ union she leads faced a vexing question: When should schools reopen?

For years, advocates of public education like Weingarten had argued that schools
played an irreplaceable role. School was where children learned academic and
social skills. It was where low-income children received subsidized meals.
Without public schools, their defenders argued, society would come apart.

On the other side of the ledger, however, was the worst pandemic in a century.
Teachers and parents feared that reopening schools before vaccines were
available would spark Covid outbreaks, illness and death.

In 2020, the pandemic’s first full year, Weingarten came down strongly on the
side of keeping schools closed. Safety measures were not enough to reopen them,
she argued. Instead, Covid became an opportunity for her union, the American
Federation of Teachers, to push for broader policy changes that it had long
favored. As my colleague Jonathan Mahler writes in a new story in the Times
Magazine
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/kCZodUAXlGZ7QZZ5uiY8AQ~~/AAAAAQA~-mp9LZP-jbBVSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]:

The A.F.T. had issued its own reopening plan in late April calling for adequate
personal protective equipment, new cleaning and sanitization regimens in school
buildings, a temporary suspension of formal teacher performance evaluations, a
limit on student testing, a cancellation of student-loan debt and a $750 billion
federal aid package to help schools prepare to reopen safely and facilitate ‘‘a
real recovery for all our communities.’’

In retrospect, the strategy seems to have failed.

Today’s newsletter, like Jonathan’s story, looks at the lingering costs to
public education.


A LOST YEAR

Many other education leaders took a different approach in 2020 and came to favor
a faster reopening of schools. In Europe, many were open
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/rsRAvNsB3TvDtWwZruMdFg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmLiSaP0TmaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMC8wNC8xNy93b3JsZC9ldXJvcGUvZGVubWFyay1zY2hvb2xzLWNvcm9uYXZpcnVzLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyOCZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTI2MSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTU3MyZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD6an0tk_6NsFVIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
by the middle of the year. In the U.S., private schools, including Catholic
schools
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/6t0xM8JZ8j4ID-IK4AltJA~~/AAAAAQA~_o2wVUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
which often have modest resources, reopened. In conservative parts of the U.S.,
public schools also reopened, at times in consultation with local teachers’
unions.

Some people did contract Covid at these schools, but the overall effect on the
virus’s spread was close to zero. U.S. communities with closed schools had
similar levels of Covid as communities with open schools, be they in the U.S. or
Europe. How could that be? By the middle of 2020, there were many other ways for
Covid to spread — in supermarkets, bars, restaurants and workplaces, as well as
homes where out-of-school children gathered with friends.

Despite the emerging data that schools were not superspreaders, many U.S.
districts remained closed well into 2021, even after vaccines were available.
About half of American children lost at least a year of full-time school,
according to Michael Hartney of Boston College.

And children suffered as a result.

They lost ground
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/pO0rTtGfhfRyWw-bVpT4Ww~~/AAAAAQA~-mp9LZP-jbBVSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
in reading, math and other subjects. The effects were worst on low-income, Black
and Latino children. Depression increased, and the American Academy of
Pediatrics declared a national emergency in children’s mental health
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/mZJOjV0GaQJgKThVnGTrWg~~/AAAAAQA~_o2wVUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].
Shamik Dasgupta, a philosopher at the University of California, Berkeley, who
became an advocate for reopening schools, called the closures “a moral
catastrophe.”

The closures also caused some Americans to sour on public schools. Nationwide
enrollment fell by 1.3 million, or 3 percent, according to the latest federal
data. The share of U.S. adults with little or no trust in public schools rose by
a few percentage points, to 33 percent, according to Gallup. In last year’s
elections, political candidates who supported vouchers — which effectively
reduce public-school funding — fared well, as Jonathan explains in his story.

“It’s pretty undeniable that the last few years have been bad for public schools
— even very bad,” he told me.


A DEMOCRATIC FAILURE

I recommend his story
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/kCZodUAXlGZ7QZZ5uiY8AQ~~/AAAAAQA~-mp9LZP-jbBVSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
because it’s a nuanced look at Weingarten and the challenges she now faces.
Republican officials have spent years trying to demonize teachers’ unions, and
Weingarten in particular (including during a House hearing this week
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/O5VhosfedvdRbxZnaTYKjA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmLiSaP4QSAWh0dHBzOi8vZWRzb3VyY2Uub3JnL3VwZGF0ZXMvdGVhY2hlcnMtdW5pb24tcHJlc2lkZW50LXJhbmRpLXdlaW5nYXJ0ZW4tdGVzdGlmaWVzLWJlZm9yZS1jb25ncmVzcy1vbi1jb3ZpZC0xOS1zY2hvb2wtY2xvc3VyZXM_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyOCZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTI2MSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTU3MyZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD6an0tk_6NsFVIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]),
and have been less successful than they hoped. In Michigan, where Weingarten
campaigned for Democrats last year, as she frequently does, the party won a
sweep of major offices. In Chicago (an overwhelmingly Democratic city), a former
teachers’ union organizer, Brandon Johnson, was elected mayor this month.

These results reflect the fact that many Americans are sympathetic to teachers
and grateful to their children’s own teachers. Teachers do vital work and don’t
make big salaries. Many spend their own money on teaching materials when schools
don’t do so.

In the case of Covid, the risks associated with reopening schools were unclear
in the spring of 2020, and teachers were understandably frightened. Over the
course of the summer, however, evidence increasingly suggested that schools
could reopen without accelerating the spread of Covid — and that the costs of
keeping them closed were steep. Despite this evidence, many schools remained
closed for months on end, even after vaccines became available.

Dasgupta, the Berkeley philosopher, has a thoughtful way of framing this
failure. As he wrote to me in an email:

It is clear that extended school closures were a mistake — they harmed children
while having no measurable effect on the pandemic. It is also clear that
teachers’ unions were a major factor behind the closures. But remember that the
unions were just doing their job. Their remit is to advocate for their members
and that is exactly what they did.

Seen like this, the problem was not the teachers’ union per se — I am personally
in favor of public sector unions — but the absence of a comparable organization
at the bargaining table to represent the interests of students and their
caregivers. It was a failure of democratic decision-making.

Looking ahead, my colleague Jonathan puts it this way:

The question (and political debate) is where do we go from here — double down on
public education, try to address the learning loss and emotional damage caused
by the pandemic closures and make an effort to restore the nation’s confidence
in public schools, or create more alternatives via school choice?

As Jonathan notes, public education is likely to be a major issue again in the
2024 campaigns. Read his story about Weingarten here
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/kCZodUAXlGZ7QZZ5uiY8AQ~~/AAAAAQA~-mp9LZP-jbBVSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].

Horten wearing the “Briolette of India.”The Heidi Horten Foundation, via
Christie's


SHINY JEWELS WITH A DARK PAST

Christie’s is preparing for a major jewelry sale next month, and the collection
— 700 jewels from the heiress Heidi Horten’s estate — is expected to bring in
more than $150 million. (For comparison, Elizabeth Taylor’s jewels sold for $137
million in 2011.)

But a painful history hangs over the auction
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/DZGWqIW5E27jTmE78KCpQw~~/AAAAAQA~_o2wVUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]:
Horten’s husband, Helmut, built his empire by buying companies from Jews who had
been forced to sell them by the Nazis, often at a steep loss. After drawing
criticism for the sale, Christie’s added a mention of the history to the auction
listing and said it would donate some proceeds to Holocaust research and
education.

-130603377.subject: Get Ready for Summer 2023!
-130603377.text:
HFGP's final newsletter of the semester!


Hey first-gen fam, 

The time has come—classes are done!

Just like that, another school year is almost over. We at HFGP are so, so proud of all that you have accomplished this year, from building healthy habits to making time to care for yourself. We know that work can get overwhelming, so we're here to remind you that you are strong and amazing for making it through. Best of luck preparing for final exams and finishing final projects.

With summer approaching, we are sharing some important notes for the end of the year and some of our favorite summer activities! This is our final newsletter of the academic year, but we'll see you (except our graduating seniors—congrats!!) again next fall.

Cheers to a happy end of another school year, and have a wonderful summer! 

Kathleen '24, Emily '24, Rafid '25, Ana '25, and Raymond '25
HFGP Coordinators 22-23


Rafid, Ana, Kathleen, Emily, and Raymond



April Team Updates

Ana

It's the final countdown! Now is the time to finish strong—in just a few weeks we'll be done! I've been staying busy with classwork as well as end-of-semester activities. As I've reflected on what I've enjoyed and how I've grown this semester, I've also been intentional about crossing things off my Harvard bucket list. With that said, I realized how much I enjoy watching sunsets by the Charles River. I hope that with your remaining time on campus, you find time to reflect and maybe even catch a sunset!

Rafid

This semester has been so much fun in terms of the classes that I have taken and the organizations I have spent time with! It has definitely been one of my busiest semesters (sophomore slump is a bit real), but it has been so rewarding. I've been trying my best to make time for myself despite all the work, and those small moments visiting a friend's dorm or going on an impromptu Boston trip have been core memories I've held dear. I can't wait to keep making more!

Emily

This semester has been super eventful for me, as I'm sure it has been for all of you! I spent the semester studying for the LSAT, preparing to write my thesis over the summer, focusing on my classes, and also, of course, spending time with friends. It was a semester full of work, but I am so grateful for my friends who encouraged me to still take time to enjoy myself by going on walks, going out for treats (Taiyaki took all my money this semester), and celebrating little milestones throughout.

Kathleen

Hey y'all! This semester has definitely been a rollercoaster. I made some great memories with friends, met so many interesting people, and experienced college through a new lens. It's always a tough balance to stay on top of classes while maintaining a social life, as well as staying physically active and getting enough sleep every night. But, as the saying goes, shoot for the moon, and land among the stars. I hope you're patting yourself on the back for getting through another semester—you deserve it! Go out and get playa bowls with friends, or as Ana suggested, sit along the Charles and enjoy the sunset.

Raymond

Hi everyone! We're at the end of April, which means biking, hiking, and jogging weather is back. A few weeks ago, I got the chance to go to NYC and perform at Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center with the Harvard-Radcliffe Collegium Musicum <https://hrcm.org/>, one of the Harvard choruses. As the busy semester comes to a close, I hope you all are feeling ok and ready for a warm, relaxing summer. Best of luck on finals!

Upcoming Events

Arts First Festival

Looking for something fun to do in the coming days? Come out to the Arts First Festival <https://ofa.fas.harvard.edu/arts>! The Arts First Festival is an annual event where student artists and organizations showcase their work. Interested in listening to a cappella music? Operas? Musicals? Come for all of these and more! The Arts First Festival starts TODAY and runs through April 30th.

Congratulations, Seniors!

Hello, seniors! As your final term comes to a close, we want to say CONGRATULATIONS! You have walked a long way, and we know you are off to great places. We wish you the best from the Harvard First Generation Program as you embark on new adventures! We want to remind you of Harvard's First Gen/Next Gen (FGLI+) Graduation Ceremony on May 23rd at 3pm. Learn more here <https://projects.iq.harvard.edu/nextgen/event/university-wide-first-gennext-gen-fgli-graduation-ceremony> and register here <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdjQqasz_9TESSZKMMqI6ybL_3KKPM7ed23q58x0VeernzUhA/viewform>!

For First-Years - Housing Day Happened: What's Next?

For all of you awesome rising sophomores, congratulations again on getting into your new favorite house and finishing your first year! Upperclass students have completed their housing lotteries, so that means you will be hearing soon about the sophomore housing questionnaire.

The housing questionnaire will ask you questions about who you would like to share a room with and your room setup preferences. Before filling out the form, be sure to chat with your blockmates so you are all on the same page! You'll also need to move out of your current first-year dorms soon (by May 14th). Here are some of HFGP's tips and reminders as you prepare to move out! 

	 Finalize storage plans and prepare to move out early! Moving out the day of or before a flight can be exhausting and stressful. If you have summer housing, you will likely be assigned a temporary storage location before summer housing opens. 
	 Sometimes, less is more! "Downsizing" truly has its benefits: you will have fewer items to move into and out of storage, and you will free up some space for your room next year. It's ok to let go of some of the things that have been hidden in your closet since the beginning of this year.
	 The Harvard Undergraduate Association (HUA) is running the Summer Storage Program again this year. For more information, check your inbox for an email from the HUA. The drop-off dates will be between May 5th-May 12th, and the boxes are sold at $15 per box. If you're interested, be sure to fill out this registration form <https://airtable.com/login?continue=%2Fshr1hvx0yR2LIFquz&redirectSource=sharedForm>.

Our Favorite Summer Activities

Whether you're going home, sticking around Cambridge and Boston, or spending your summer in a new place, here are a some of our favorite activities to get excited about.

	 Throw a frisbee and go picnicking at a park.	 If you'll be in Cambridge, try Cambridge Commons. The grass is always open, and the field is a great place to settle down on a sunny day! 


	 Go for a bike ride or hike.	 If you'll be in Cambridge, Memorial Drive, right along the Charles River, is closed off on Sundays for recreational use. Take a walk or bike ride there when the weather gets nicer.


	 Grab ice cream or boba with friends.	 If you'll be in Cambridge, there is no lack of ice cream shops...Lizzy's, Taiyaki NYC, Ben and Jerry's, J.P. Licks, Gongcha, Tiger Sugar, and more. If you want to venture over to Porter Square, check out Honeycomb!


	 Go thrifting.	 There are several thrift stores in Cambridge and Boston, and they're all awesome! From Boomerang's in Central Square to Make & Mend in Somerville (a second-hand art store), you'll find all sorts of goods at affordable prices.


	 Plan a day trip!	 Wherever you'll be, hopefully, you'll be able to take some time off and explore new places. This could be a new big city, a beach, a historical site, or just a place with a view. Take some time to be adventurous this summer! If you are around Boston, we recommend day trips to Cape Cod, Portsmouth (NH), Walden Pond, or Newport (RI).





Self-Care During Finals

Avoid Burnout!

With final exams coming up, make sure to take care of yourself! Get a meal with a friend or go for a workout to get some endorphins flowing. 

Make sure to get an adequate amount of sleep. This will help you retain information and feel better rested to help manage any stressors. 

Don't forget to drink water! Dehydration can impact cognitive performance, so you owe it to yourself to get those eight glasses.


Do Something Fun

Do something fun and get your mind off work. Have a picnic along the Charles River. Grab an ice cream. Go to a social. You might find that doing something fun will help you stay focused for longer! 

Plan Your Reading Period in Advance

Plan out what your reading period days will look like in advance. This way you can know what to expect for each day, and how the bulk of your days will be structured before exams and final essays or project deadlines are upon you.


Returning students, remember that financial aid applications are due on May 1st!

(617) 495-1581 (Griffin Financial Aid Office)

-2040331771.subject: [Bacch-talk]  CID News + Opportunities: April 24
-2040331771.text:
[image: HARVARD Kennedy School | Center for International Development]
<https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=daba8ac99de7c8a68ee361f76a12bf4f6be974b16c21ea4d860a8fdadc9a28ad195606e43310ff9263bdd003e55fcbddfa27c369723243f0>


*News + Opportunities**April 24, 2023*



Events











[image: Pedagogies of Belonging: Microportrait Launch poster]
Pedagogies of Belonging: Microportrait Launch REACH, HGSE Webinar

*Date:* April 26, 2023
*Time:* 9AM - 10AM ET
*Location:* Virtual

*Speakers*: Sarah Dryden-Peterson
<https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1f13dcc918fd6be192b7678d6b408a5c647549d6bda0bc08f04acf7ccd4350746e694117c7397763da04cbe4f91e157ebf>,
Professor of Education, Harvard GSE, accompanied by various authors of
microportraits.

*About the talk*
This webinar will launch the new book, *Pedagogies of Belonging: Educators
Building Welcoming Communities in Settings of Conflict & Migration*. This
book is about educators and for educators, and the practices they have
developed to create welcoming communities in settings of migration. Each
page of the book is a “microportrait” of an educator who the authors have
come to know by spending time in their classroom and school. Join for a
conversation about how educators are building welcoming communities,
creating space for dissent, for dialogue, for trust, for new identities,
for future-building, and how they are envisioning and building newly
imagined communities.



*Register
<https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1f25d2b5f841c87ff01f9650063349cdc21667d3e9d5b068067bc78397852e34926170a878daa9181bf49d8a47abec750f>*







The aftermath of the Turkey and Syria earthquakes – updates from first
responders  CID Webinar

*Date:* April 27, 2023
*Time:* 12PM - 1PM ET
*Location:* Virtual

*Speakers*:
Mia Tong, Research and Policy Officer at Kadın Emeğini Değerlendirme Vakfı
(Turkey).
Hazem Rihawi, Sr. Program Manager at the American Relief Coalition for
Syria.

*Moderator*: Jennifer Leaning
<https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1fd298e1cfba75a952e54b881162f38aa805c3c7f4d589f4a0fd37e72c6e2322a3f2816e9f1a60637d02759230744d47c1>,
Senior Fellow at the Harvard FXB Center; Previous Professor of the Practice
of Health and Human Rights, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health.

*About the talk*
On 6 February 2023, two devastating earthquakes struck southern and central
Turkey and northern and western Syria. There has been widespread damage and
tens of thousands of fatalities since. On April 27, 2023, The Center for
International Development (CID) presents Hazem Rihawi, a Sr. Program
Manager at the American Relief Coalition for Syria, and Mia Tong, a
Research and Policy Officer at Kadın Emeğini Değerlendirme Vakfı (Turkey).
Mia and Hazem will share their first accounts as first respondents
responders in the aftermath of the earthquakes. They will provide an update
on the evolving humanitarian response, perspectives of how well the
international community supports local partners during this time, and what
steps we must take now and more long-term to support frontline communities
facing disasters.



*Register
<https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1ff02e465f4a41b20949de799213c3f3d12a438eb02f07d3729f6325a66329ed289cb5d06eba8e0f78bcc4da3c35e04122>*







[image: Susan Kenniston headshot]
The private sector’s sustainability awakening – industry trends and global
impact  A CID Road to GEM23 event

*Date:* April 28, 2023
*Time:* 12PM - 1PM ET
*Location:* T-520 Alison Dining Room & Virtual **NEW LOCATION*

*Speakers*: Susan Kenniston, Global Head & VP - Sustainability at Wipro.

*About the event*
CID presents Susan Kenniston, Global Head & VP - Sustainability at Wipro
who will discuss her experience building, leading, and delivering
Sustainability solutions across industries and the role of the private
sector to tackle the climate crisis.

CID's "Road to GEM23" climate and development series precedes and helps
launch CID’s Global Empowerment Meeting (GEM23): Growing in a Green World
<https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1f0d36dc9d5744bf5a6d5814941124e80a441be3bcb602ef235e13df654bf1a966b18f315b5ba1b1caf3f9740843147559>
taking
place in May. This spring, CID strives to elevate and learn from voices
from the countries on the frontlines of the climate crisis and also feature
important learnings from the leaders who will be active participants at
GEM23.

This is a hybrid event open virtually to the public and in-person at the
Harvard Kennedy School for members of the Harvard Community. Lunch will be
served.



*Register for the event
<https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1fdb5a9a9e666c4b37a3e407e040c426680d8b5b40393f8558d00075347acd4486d0f609bc32e16fb984cc5a3aee9a3b93>*



*Harvard students can also register to take part in an in-person,
roundtable career chat from 1:30-2:30pm with Susan Kenniston after her
talk. Registration is required and will close once room has hit capacity. *


*Register for the group career chat
<https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1fe5880a16502f4b3f63beb8461dc53fb7be17143da2f9a721b10be3fda75e0552db241365037aa0fb1668dd73f8f8d5cd>*






CID Undergraduate Career Roundtables with Samira Khan and Qahir Dhanani



*Date:* May 1, 2023
*Time:* 2:45PM - 4:00PM
*Location:* Wex-434A.B Conference Room

*Speakers*:
Samira Khan
<https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1f18a1f0ed0699464039371c96ef4465f39656d1003597e8513d250d40d94e396bcc330ea78443556475718e28787fe23c>,
Director of Field & Campaign Insights, Global Public Affairs, Microsoft;
MPP, Harvard Kennedy School.
Qahir Dhanani
<https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1f775b26cd37dbc1a61b4ce264ca6f8dbd1d0df1592ebb68e520372ed219fa7e4a77c0a6fdcd8abdf6518126039b5a8525>,
Partner & Associate Director, Boston Consulting Group; MBA, Harvard
Business School; MPP, Harvard Kennedy School.

*About the event*
CID is pleased to invite Samira Khan and Qahir Dhanani, two leading experts
in addressing global development issues, to lead two simultaneous career
roundtable chats. The roundtable chat is geared towards providing career
advice for undergraduate students interested in international development
as they seek to find opportunities in the field for internships or
post-graduation careers.

*About Samira Khan*
Samira Khan is a social impact innovator and intrapreneur with a passion
for empathy-driven solutions that promote societal well-being and address
global challenges. With 15 years of experience across sectors, she
currently serves as a director within Global Public Affairs at Microsoft,
having previously worked at the intersection of social innovation and
technology at Microsoft and Salesforce. Samira is committed to empowering
people through entrepreneurship, innovation, and creative partnerships that
span regions and socioeconomic lines. She focuses on fostering transparent
access to knowledge and cross-pollination of ideas to drive capital
commitments towards the SDGs, sustainability, and well-being technology.
Her work targets vulnerable communities, particularly Black and Brown
populations in the US, Asia, and emerging markets.

*About Qahir Dhanani:*
Qahir Dhanani is a Partner & Associate Director at the Boston Consulting
Group (BCG), where he plays a central role in the firm's leadership team
focused on global economic and social development. With over 15 years of
experience, Qahir has advised senior executives and officials across
public, private, and social sectors on policy and programmatic issues,
including climate action, poverty alleviation, jobs, competitiveness,
infrastructure, innovation, and entrepreneurship. His expertise also
extends to operational matters such as agile, organizational
transformation, process excellence, change management, and leadership
development. Before joining BCG, Qahir served as an Advisor to the CEO at
the World Bank and held various positions within the Aga Khan Development
Network, showcasing his commitment to driving positive change in global
communities.

*This event is open to members of the Harvard Community and is geared
towards undergraduates at Harvard College.*



*Register to join a Career Roundtable with Amira or Qahir
<https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1f95c4a47340255b3232afaee6b2a36626b7f932aacb22ece3b77c83866a3ee0c32aedb754987f875ce0cd469bb88ada9b>*







*CID is pleased to share events and activities that focus on issues in
international development that are hosted by centers and departments across
Harvard University. Please e-mail cid@harvard.edu
<cid@harvard.edu?subject=> if you would like us to consider sharing your
event in this newsletter.*


CID-led Opportunities





   - *GEM23 undergraduate climate art contest
   <https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1fd715b5a31116637060bc1583f7ce215534000311c16052406c31c158592effd6c0c5de5781752638ca7935839ec6882b>*:
   CID and the Harvard Climate Coalition are hosting an undergraduate climate
   art competition for students to submit their work in alignment with the
   theme CID’s Global Empowerment Meeting 2023 (GEM23)
   <https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1fe96c7f3b1f7bfd2ce7f5981c329e3da06d9dd56808af8c495d201187091c3ec7fbaea665c1e433a931f20ecb03bc8a62>,
   Growing in a Green World. Submissions are open to artistic interpretation,
   and all forms of media are encouraged. Art will be displayed and judged at
   the conference for a chance to win a Visa Gift Card. *Submissions are
   due by May 1st at 11:55pm*. Read more about the process here
   <https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1f372b16c95156d00a21091e8cbf211c3567ac0867db9889e582ba896c2e99c9c4f00df6d58577071cbf676f29e1fc0811>
   .


Harvard Opportunities





   - *HKS Summer Funding*
   <https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1fe26f72736a136b2b269755af9924c6e8689204b4d0d6ed915bd3bf9d309247cdd7553257155182e3bc02cbab29cf2aaf>:
   The HKS common application for summer internship funding is now open. There
   are three summer funding closing/review periods, but some funders may
   choose to end their process after the first review period. The general
   internship requirements state that for most centers and required for SIF,
   an internship must be a minimum of eight weeks, full-time, in a public or
   NGO. Please note that some funders have specific application
requirements. *Round
   III (if funding is still available): Rolling basis from April 28–May 26,
   2023.*


Other Opportunities





   - Good Business Lab (GBL) is hiring
   <https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1f09e6007bfd66ad4d0e77932b2e25e3b49e8dae566cf6c7f64cba9a3dda85c891c3fe642867839d7cca390f889fbc68b5>
in
   Ann Arbor, Michigan. GBL was founded in 2017 as a research-based startup by
   two academics from the University of Michigan and the head of
   organizational development at Shahi Exports, India's largest apparel
   exporter. GBL uses rigorous research methods to drive wellbeing outcomes
   for all workers across various supply chains.


CID Job Openings





   - *Growth Lab Research Assistant*
   <https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1f2b1aba414795e7cd51ccd6ee5c643579fc9bffb257ab8aa40000016779e34cc0e6f86befc9f3f384a44ce69d54fee52d>:
   Harvard’s Growth Lab has an immediate opening for a full-time Research
   Assistant to contribute to a range of research projects. As an important
   part of our research teams, they will gain valuable experience working with
   faculty and research fellows on international development research and
   policy.


   - *Growth Lab Executive Coordinator*
   <https://click.comms.hks.harvard.edu/?qs=18021125ec008d1f11515c9994470bd0181314be2da82fe434b73c3cc0215017b315de4ffa0c37f4368f49f4325239b0ebd9ab93bcff3283>:
   The Executive Coordinator provides high quality administrative, logistical
   and course support to the Faculty Director, and serves as the first point
   of contact and liaison to faculty, fellows, staff, students, and high-level
   external contacts.







*Center for International Development at Harvard University*

-1276982414.subject: [Bacch-talk]  May Day Poetry Reading
-1276982414.text:
An Introduction to Poetry

~Billy Collins (professor, and former US poet laureate)

I ask them to take a poem
and hold it up to the light
like a color slide
or press an ear against its hive.

I say drop a mouse into a poem
and watch him probe his way out,

or walk inside the poem’s room
and feel the walls for a light switch.

I want them to waterski
across the surface of a poem
waving at the author’s name on the shore.

But all they want to do
is tie the poem to a chair with rope
and torture a confession out of it.

They begin beating it with a hose
to find out what it really means.

--------------------------------

MAY*DAY*POETRY*READING

May the First, 7:00pm

Senior Common Room

Come join us to celebrate spring
[New leukemia treatment developed from common wild flower]

-160777023.subject: [Bacch-talk]  Fwd: [Kuumba] Kuumba's Half-Century Celebration: May 5th - 7th
-160777023.text:
Come Join Us for

KUUMBA’s Half-Century Celebration

[image: FINAL KUUMBA POSTER.png]

on the weekend of May 5-7, 2023

Events Including…..

Our Annual Concert on May 6th,

(get tickets here!
<https://www.boxoffice.harvard.edu/Online/default.asp?BOparam::WScontent::loadArticle::permalink=events>
)

Keynote Talk w/ Former Attorney General Loretta Lynch,

&

More !

The Half Century Celebration of the Kuumba Singers of Harvard College is an
unabashed celebration of Kuumba, a choir fellowship founded by Black
undergraduate students who sought safe harbor in a strange land. Forged in
the crucible of the racial and social unrest of the 1970s, Kuumba has not
only grown but prospered, passing forward its core spiritual and cultural
values, and its passion for justice for more than a half-century.



-- 
*Angie Gabeau*
*Director of Publicity | The Kuumba Singers of Harvard College *
Student Organization Center at Hilles
Office #O352
59 Shepard Street
Cambridge, MA 02138

By Melissa Kirsch
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/CWyDGM6KY5hw649kyQ_RKg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmL3QOP0S_aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvbWVsaXNzYS1raXJzY2g_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyOSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTM2NyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTY3NSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD4O70xk_yYrsVIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]

Good morning. The books we read when we’re young help shape the adults we become
in ways we don’t always grasp.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/29/multimedia/29-THE-MORNING-NL/29-THE-MORNING-NL-jumbo.jpg]María
Jesús Contreras


PRETEEN SENSATIONS

If you ask any kids who grew up reading Judy Blume, they’ll tell you precisely
what they learned from each of Blume’s books; which taboo rites of passage each
book introduced; probably even where they were, physically and developmentally,
when they first stumbled on this information. They might very well remember the
precise page number of the paperback that was passed around middle school on
which the most eye-opening passages appeared.

I recently reread her classic, “Are You There God? It’s Me, Margaret,” in
advance of seeing the film adaptation
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/Y_xW1SbknazfKOOLCOqGfw~~/AAAAAQA~-Du9MZP8mK7FSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
that opens this week, 52 years after the book’s publication.

In my memory, “Margaret” was chiefly about puberty, specifically about getting
your period for the first time. I vividly remembered the famous scenes when
Margaret first encounters sanitary napkins and when she and her friends do
exercises in order to “get out of those baby bras,” chanting, “We must — we must
— we must increase our bust!”

As I reread the book, though, I was struck not only by its Big Moments, but also
by the many small, almost trivial ones that I’d unwittingly assimilated into my
understanding of the world.

There’s an early scene in which Margaret’s father injures himself while mowing
the lawn and Margaret runs out into the yard “to look for the limb,” in case the
doctor might be able to sew it back on.

I stopped short. This scene was as real to me as one of my own memories. When
I’d read the book as an adolescent, it was the first time I’d heard about such a
grisly surgical procedure. I didn’t actively think of it again, but “you should
always look for the limb” became part of my smart aleck’s understanding of the
world, a bit of wisdom, never questioned. I never tied this knowledge back to
the book or any source.

“Margaret” also instilled in me the belief that wearing loafers with socks makes
one “look like a baby” and that it was possible to get a custom label made for a
homemade sweater that said “Made Expressly for You … by Grandma.” Small details,
certainly not the main themes of the book, not what I’d tell any adult at the
time that I “took away” from reading it.

“Margaret” the movie — which you should see if you loved the book, or loved the
director Kelly Fremon Craig’s first film, “Edge of Seventeen” — is full of these
details, moments that change a young reader quietly. Watching it, I felt little
electrical connections being made between my childhood brain and my adult brain,
between the data that was inputted decades ago and the coherent knowledge it’s
become.


FOR MORE

 * Blume, Fremon Craig and the film’s stars discussed the novel’s cultural
   impact
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/UyA1D8t67QzYy24WjEntqA~~/AAAAAQA~_JiuxUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].
 * “Somebody used to say to me, ‘Just wait till all these kids who grew up with
   you get to those positions of power in Hollywood — you will see.’” Blume on
   how the “Margaret” film finally came to be
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/AXtnolM2njYGo8Vh8KTG2g~~/AAAAAQA~-Du9MZP8mK7FSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].
 * “To us, Margaret Simon wasn’t a character, she was a proxy — for the girl who
   stuffed socks in her bra, who felt uncomfortable in her own skin; for the
   girl who was homesick for a friend who had matured overnight or moved away or
   turned mean; for the girl who struggled to make sense of the diagrams on the
   origami-folded instructions inside the tampon box.” The Times’s Elisabeth
   Egan on the book’s enduring appeal.
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/lU_xIkKX_DanKkKhPXAq_A~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmL3QOP0TyaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNy9ib29rcy9qdWR5LWJsdW1lLWFyZS15b3UtdGhlcmUtaXRzLW1lLW1hcmdhcmV0LW1vdmllLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyOSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTM2NyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTY3NSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD4O70xk_yYrsVIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
 * From April 2020, Cheryl Strayed’s podcast interview
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/KTNNBDt5tHDMa-dYTbExNg~~/AAAAAQA~-Du9MZP8mK7FSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   with Blume.

Continue reading the main story
