[https://liveintent.newyorktimesinfo.com/imp?s=859187&li=NN&m=fa60ce664779ffc4229588105bf228e7&p=NN_20230429]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/h6oFgWOqTOTkAA3K7q7iVA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmL3QOP0SWaHR0cHM6Ly9saXZlaW50ZW50Lm5ld3lvcmt0aW1lc2luZm8uY29tL2NsaWNrP3M9ODU5MTg3JmxpPU5OJm09ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTcmcD1OTl8yMDIzMDQyOSZ0ZT0xJm5sPXRoZS1tb3JuaW5nJmVtYz1lZGl0X25uXzIwMjMwNDI5VwNueXRCCmQ-Du9MZP8mK7FSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~


THE WEEK IN CULTURE

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/28/multimedia/29-THE-MORNING-NL-harry/29-THE-MORNING-NL-harry-jumbo.jpg]Harry
Belafonte.(Photo by Keystone/Getty Images)

 * Cool and charismatic, Harry Belafonte, who died this week at 96, channeled
   his stardom
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/NksE5X4V7nrb14t3MfjNAg~~/AAAAAQA~_JiuxUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
   into activism. (Watch some of his greatest screen performances
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/of5e9dtXJMUlVu4UIKFPQQ~~/AAAAAQA~-Du9MZP8mK7FSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].)
 * Jerry Springer, who died this week at 79, was a talk show populist who threw
   the studio doors open, and all hell broke through
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/cDTn9ntsYNmze069NB_eVQ~~/AAAAAQA~_JiuxUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].
 * Ed Sheeran testified in court, defending his song “Thinking Out Loud”
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ZvYFzsuz1b0BZmQoVg-AHg~~/AAAAAQA~-Du9MZP8mK7FSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   against an accusation that he copied it from Marvin Gaye’s “Let’s Get It On.”
 * What qualifies as stealing a song? Hear examples from other famous music
   trials
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/GU52b40L8lGE3pzBUtX6XA~~/AAAAAQA~_JiuxUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
   involving George Harrison, Led Zeppelin and Katy Perry.
 * “He was always looking ahead to the next thing”: Anna Wintour remembers the
   Karl Lagerfeld designs
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/CZuvFyhRpWvUCWoFQNtUXQ~~/AAAAAQA~-Du9MZP8mK7FSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   she wore. The Met Gala will honor his work on Monday. (See his defining looks
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/JdI58rMVyuf0ArpNO-zIOg~~/AAAAAQA~-Du9MZP8mK7FSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].)
 * Karin Hindsbo, a Danish-born museum executive, will lead the Tate Modern
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/rGLwunp3nbZDTCSI2jbljw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmL3QOP0TjaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yOC9hcnRzL2Rlc2lnbi90YXRlLW1vZGVybi1rYXJpbi1oaW5kc2JvLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyOSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTM2NyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTY3NSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD4O70xk_yYrsVIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
   in London, one of the world’s most popular museums.
 * The BBC’s chairman resigned over his role in a loan for former Prime Minister
   Boris Johnson of Britain, deepening the turmoil at the broadcaster
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/daCTZnMA1wJsKtPLus9elg~~/AAAAAQA~-Du9MZP8mK7FSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].

 * Carrie Bradshaw is back for a new season of “And Just Like That …” The show
   released its trailer for Season 2
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/7auJoImH9wrj_0KmmrThZg~~/AAAAAQA~-Du9MZP8mK7FSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].
 * Celebrities came out for Time’s 100 Most Influential People in the World

   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/mTQxzneP_kcXGz8fAED7JA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmL3QOP0TdaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNy9zdHlsZS90aW1lLTEwMC1nYWxhLXNhdmUtdmVuaWNlLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyOSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTM2NyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTY3NSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD4O70xk_yYrsVIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~].
 * A scramble to finish scripts and late-night shows’ contingency plans:
   Hollywood is bracing for a writers’ strike
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ORR8JJBMSI7n17y8p4NjIA~~/AAAAAQA~_JiuxUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].
 * Is Tom Ford saying farewell to fashion
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/U4CeQ3apnhleHWKn9SBsSg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmL3QOP0TdaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNi9zdHlsZS90b20tZm9yZC1maW5hbC1jb2xsZWN0aW9uLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyOSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTM2NyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTE5ODUwMjg2NSZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTY3NSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9ZmE2MGNlNjY0Nzc5ZmZjNDIyOTU4ODEwNWJmMjI4ZTdXA255dEIKZD4O70xk_yYrsVIZYXpodW9AY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]?
 * Imane Anys, known online as Pokimane, is a star in the world of video games
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/leLMfYYO_PYr3NsMPU84vw~~/AAAAAQA~_JiuxUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].
   That puts her on the front lines of the internet’s culture wars.

📚 “Trust” (Tuesday): In this novel by Hernan Diaz, now available in paperback,
the life of an early 20th-century New York financier is told from four different
perspectives. Named one of The Times’s 10 best books of 2022
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/e6chTPKF2qB08OKyIQ4lcg~~/AAAAAQA~_JiuxUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
we called “Trust” an “exhilarating pursuit.”

🍿 “Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3” (Friday): One of the few directors to hop
back and forth between the Marvel Cinematic Universe and the DC Extended
Universe, James Gunn is taking one more swing with Star Lord and Co. before
taking on yet another Superman reboot. Expect jokes, classic rock tunes and
light profanity.

ARTICHOKE CARBONARA

Whether you’re planning a festive spring gathering or looking to make yourself
something extra special for dinner this weekend, Anna Francese Gass’s delightful
artichoke carbonara
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/cooking/Ee2U_t8S7T-6HSsiyLPE3Q~~/AAAAAQA~-Du9MZP8mK7FSGWF6aHVvQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
might be just the thing. In her clever recipe, she levels up an easy weeknight
pasta by stirring in canned or frozen artichoke quarters, adding flavor and
texture without much effort. For a vegetarian version, skip the pancetta and
caramelize some onions or mushrooms in the pan instead. Then top each bowl with
a raw egg yolk for the silkiest carbonara sauce imaginable.

ADVICE FROM WIRECUTTER


MAKE YOUR COLD BREW

Unless you’re a year-round iced coffee hound, you may be making the annual
transition from hot drip to cold brew. At the coffee shop, that can be a
splurge, but at home, switching to cold brew might actually save you money. A
good cold brew maker, like Wirecutter’s pick from OXO
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/tqPOhe-23T2YV_KvF0apyw~~/AAAAAQA~_JiuxUhlhemh1b0Bjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
can smooth out the rough edges of inexpensive, mediocre beans, producing a
sweet, mellow concentrate that will last all week. I even like to brew the same
grounds twice — coffee pros might disapprove, but the results are great,
especially with a splash of milk. — Marguerite Preston


GAME OF THE WEEKEND

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/29/multimedia/29-THE-MORNING-NL-hockey-vlqk/29-THE-MORNING-NL-hockey-vlqk-jumbo-v2.jpg]Frank
Franklin Ii/Associated Press

New Jersey Devils vs. New York Rangers, N.H.L. playoffs: These two teams are so
close that you could probably see one arena from the roof of the other without
the skyscrapers in the way. Maybe that’s why they have each looked so
comfortable in away games: The Rangers started the series with two blowout wins
in Newark, and then the Devils won two games in Manhattan. The Devils now lead
the series, 3-2, and can advance with a win tonight. Good news for them: The
game is in New York. 8 p.m. Eastern on ABC.

-787007763.subject: [cs-undergrads] Fwd: Research Assistant Opportunity - CS Skills Required
-787007763.text:
Hi everyone! Professor Emmerich Davies is looking for a research assistant.
I will copy below the information:

We are looking for someone to assist us in building a corpus suitable for
Natural Language Processing from thousands of pages of textbooks. Because
textbooks have irregular formatting, we need someone to first develop an
approach that learns the format of a textbook page, and then extracts the
text from the textbook page in a reasonable format. For example, in the
following textbook page, we would need to record the page number, the
chapter title (“Medieval India”), the section header (“Shah Jahan”) and the
picture caption. We also need the text to be saved accurately, which
requires identifying that there are two columns of text, and the page reads
from left to right by column.

We recommend starting with Melissa Dell’s layoutparser package, and seeing
if it can perform well on our textbook corpus.

Contact Emmerich at emmerich_davies_escobar@gse.harvard.edu if you're
interested or have any questions :)

--

-453929908.subject: How can we foster students’ collaboration skills?
-453929908.text:
Fostering Collaboration Skills in the Classroom

View this email in your browser (https://mailchi.mp/harvard/rosalea-monacella?e=7d1f100abc)
https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=f77fdb0b01&e=7d1f100abc
Harvard Initiative for Learning and Teaching (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=298ecae7b6&e=7d1f100abc)   |  Data Science & Technology (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=7fe3d3f6df&e=7d1f100abc)   |  Harvard Online (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=d452075929&e=7d1f100abc)


** Into Practice
------------------------------------------------------------


** Timely teaching advice and research findings
------------------------------------------------------------


** Fostering Collaboration Skills in the Classroom
------------------------------------------------------------
HIGHLIGHT: When students leave the university, many will enter fields that require strong collaboration skills. Thus, it is imperative that instructors provide intentional opportunities for students to develop these skill sets.
https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=9226792836&e=7d1f100abc Monacella, Design Critic in Landscape Architecture at the Graduate School of Design (GSD), works to create opportunities for students to build collaborative skills and facilitate peer-to-peer learning by “embed[ding] the techniques of joint problem-solving and ideas development” in her design studio courses (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=b29f86564d&e=7d1f100abc) . Monacella starts by fostering a classroom community built on mutual respect and trust, modelling and scaffolding collaborative behaviours to help students develop their unique individual capacities through collaborative work. She has found that instructors often assume that students know how to work effectively in group settings; however, oftentimes, students have never been provided with scaffolded experiences that will help them develop their group working styles.
The benefits: Monacella aims to provide students with the skillsets they will need in highly collaborative interdisciplinary environments. Students learn techniques and approaches in action, rather than simply being told what they are. Students are thus able to apply those techniques and approaches to new settings, and even develop their own methods as a result. Monacella has found that by deliberately integrating this professional development into the curriculum rather than expecting it to simply happen naturally, students gain an increased level of comfort and confidence when approaching new materials and when seeking and providing feedback, both inside and outside the classroom.


** “We underestimate the amount of learning that happens through peer-to-peer exchange. We assume that knowledge is predominantly transferred from instructor to learner, but what I continually find is that teaching certain concepts and forms of knowledge is most effective when it is repeated and unpacked through a peer-to-peer exchange.”
------------------------------------------------------------
The challenges: Effective peer-to-peer learning relies heavily on full participation from the class; thus, preparation and student buy-in is necessary. Monacella has found that she must be able to adapt to the cohort dynamics, which occasionally shift and require in-class adjustments to her teaching and learning plan. Additionally, she has found that despite the best intentions and time-consuming plans, sometimes, pedagogical experiments aren’t effective, and instructors must be able to rebound in the moment to shift gears.
Takeaways and best practices
* Shift the Hierarchy. Monacella “consciously tries to shift the hierarchy of the room” to create a learning environment where students feel empowered to ask questions, challenge the instructor and each other respectfully, and solve problems together rather than relying on the instructor as the only source of answers or critique.
* Switch up Your Toolbox. In the design studio, Monacella aims to implement peer learning in different ways throughout the semester rather than relying on the same activities during each session. From small group problem solving activities to workshops featuring direct feedback to roundtable discussions, she tries to shift the structure week to week.
* Be Transparent About Your Approach. Monacella has found that explaining her peer learning-centred pedagogical approach to students has increased its effectiveness. Prior to each class, she sends out the plan for the session along with a quick explanation of the session’s intent and why she chose to structure it in that particular way. Thus, students know what to expect and come to class fully prepared to participate and are less wary of new activities.

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
Related Teaching Efforts

Instructional Moves (IM) (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=8d98e29bbf&e=7d1f100abc) featured faculty member Eric Mazur (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=2c4411b001&e=7d1f100abc) (SEAS, FAS) regularly uses team-based learning (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=3de8b6a075&e=7d1f100abc) in his undergraduate physics classes. Throughout his courses, he builds in a number of supports for peer learning, from a classroom climate that encourages process over product (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=ab0ac33aa2&e=7d1f100abc) to contracts that foster team building (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=be2959f02a&e=7d1f100abc) .

In addition to these resources, IM has a large raw clips library that features many unedited clips of classroom footage showing moments of peer learning (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=50118ddf35&e=7d1f100abc) across schools at Harvard. These clips illustrate a large variety of activities that lend themselves to peer learning.

If your students would benefit from extending their collaborations beyond the classroom, encourage them to book a group study room with the Library's Find a Space (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=23675477d3&e=7d1f100abc) tool.
Relevant Research

To learn more (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=a58504adce&e=7d1f100abc) about active learning and how to overcome student resistance to peer instruction, check out Louis Deslauriers, et al. (2019) article on the value of active learning and how to combat the challenges.

Peer feedback is frequently implemented in post-secondary classrooms and has great potential for improving students’ writing skills. However, research shows (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=0c71cd6310&e=7d1f100abc) that the impact of peer feedback is dependent on its quality, and thus, students need to be taught how to provide quality, effective critiques.
Related Resources and Opportunities

Explore resources on peer learning (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=c1a5431c70&e=7d1f100abc) curated from the Harvard Initiative for Learning and Teaching (HILT) 2019 Conference.

Check out this article “Overcoming Peer Learning Phobia (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=4cc4a283d8&e=7d1f100abc) ” about best practices for peer learning at Harvard Kennedy School.

Check out this article on the logistics of creating active learning spaces (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=f5b7fa16f8&e=7d1f100abc) from Harvard Business Publishing.

Interested in implementing active learning in your classroom (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=cdf2fde5f5&e=7d1f100abc) ? Visit the Bok Center for Teaching and Learning’s ABLConnect (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=a0733a13b9&e=7d1f100abc) online database for activities and inspiration.

Looking for a quick overview of active learning strategies? Visit the Harvard Graduate School of Education Teaching Guide for Active Learning Strategies (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=4bfdc9b006&e=7d1f100abc) .
MORE FACULTY FEATURES (https://harvard.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=22e759bc06&e=7d1f100abc)
Connect http://twitter.com/share?url=https%3A%2F%2Fmailchi.mp%2Fharvard%2Frosalea-monacella&text=How+can+we+foster+students%E2%80%99+collaboration+skills%3F+via+%40HarvardHILT&count=none

Forward to a colleague (https://us3.forward-to-friend.com/forward?u=fdc1ecde9767cd86216498053&id=7191d1f15f&e=7d1f100abc)  or send feedback and suggestions (mailto:viceprovost_learning@harvard.edu?subject=Into%20Practice) .

-2143579960.subject: [HUES] TODAY @ 2:30: Nuclear Energy Summit
-2143579960.text:
Hi everyone,

Interested in climate change and decarbonization? Interested in foreign
affairs and policy as they intersect with technology? Thinking about
joining HUTT next year?

*The Harvard Undergraduate Think Tank* cordially invites you to attend our
inaugural symposium this Friday, April 28th in the Fong Auditorium in *Boylston
Hall!* We will be hosting a session presented by one of our advocacy teams:


*The Future of Nuclear Energy in the United States (2:45-4pm)*

This event will include presentations by our undergraduate research teams
as well as moderated discussions and Q&A sessions with experts in the
field. And there will be *free Flour Bakery* catering for all attendees!

See attached flyer for details.

We hope to see all who are interested this Friday!

Best,
HUTT Co-Presidents
Arjun Akwei and Shelby Tzung

[image: HUTT Symposium - Nuclear.png]

-- 
*Ben Schroeder *(He/Him)
Harvard University | Class of 2024
S.B. Candidate in Mechanical Engineering
Secondary in History

--

Third Edition of An Elementary Introduction to the Wolfram Language 
<https://www.amazon.com/Elementary-Introduction-Wolfram-Language-Third/dp/1944183078>


The third edition of An Elementary Introduction to the Wolfram Language is now 
available, which provides a comprehensive introduction to Wolfram Language—the 
language behind the Wolfram plugin for ChatGPT. This updated edition features 
new content throughout and a new section on audio and video processing.

Order Now 
<https://www.amazon.com/Elementary-Introduction-Wolfram-Language-Third/dp/1944183078>



 
 
<https://www.amazon.com/Elementary-Introduction-Wolfram-Language-Third/dp/1944183078>

An Elementary Introduction to the Wolfram Language is suitable for individuals 
with no prior programming experience. It includes interactive code examples 
runnable in any Wolfram environment.


To learn more, visit the Wolfram Media site 
<https://www.wolfram-media.com/products/an-elementary-introduction-to-the-wolfram-language/>
.

-354368412.subject: [Bacch-talk]  Fwd: [NOTES ON LOVE] Join us for a night of art, tech, love! (5/1)
-354368412.text:
*Tonight, 7 PM, the Advocate Building! *

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Conflux Harvard <conflux.harvard@gmail.com>
Date: Sat, Apr 29, 2023 at 2:15 PM
Subject: [NOTES ON LOVE] Join us for a night of art, tech, love! (5/1)
To: <confluxharvard@googlegroups.com>


Join us at the Advocate this Monday, May 1st at 7pm for "Notes on Love," an
evening of art-tech projects and genuine conversations centered around the
theme of life, love, and connection between people.

There will be beautiful art-tech projects and visualizations, food and
drinks, and conversations all around the theme of life and love. Submit an
anonymous letter to a person you love here and look at one visualization of
love: https://www.noteson.love/submit/

[image: Notes on Love (2).png]

--
